context: Attorneys for a criminal defendant charged that the government, in a cover-up, had destroyed evidence that would have supported the defendant in a case. The government replied that there is no evidence that would even tend to support the defendant in the case.
question: Why is it not correct to conclude that, if true, the government's reply effectively disproves the charge made on behalf of the defendant?
answer0: Saying that there "is no evidence" would be true whether it had never existed or if it had been destroyed.
answer1: If the evidence really doesn't exist, it wouldn't have been found whether or not the government searched for it.
answer2: The government's response does not prove or even insinuate that the attorneys didn't know whether their charge was true or not.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The average hourly wage of television assemblers in Vernland has long been significantly lower than that in neighboring Borodia. Since Borodia dropped all tariffs on Vernlandian televisions three years ago, the number of televisions sold annually in Borodia has not changed. However, recent statistics show a drop in the number of television assemblers in Borodia. Ttherefore, updated trade statistics will probably indicate that the number of televisions Borodia imports annually from Vernland has increased.
question: Why does the argument not depend on the assumption that televisions assembled in Vernland have features that televisions assembled in Borodia do not have?
answer0: Whether or not the hourly wage of television assemblers goes up or down in the future would not affect the sale of televisions currently.
answer1: The argument implies that the sales of televisions from Vernland has gone up not because they are more desirable, but because they are less expensive due to low labor costs.
answer2: Vernland would not necessarily need to increase its number of television assemblers in order to sell more televisions to Borodia, as they may instead be importing fewer televisions to other countries, selling fewer domestically, or selling stock that would not otherwise have sold.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The use of radar detectors in commercial vehicles was banned because commercial truck and bus drivers were using these devices to drive faster than the posted speed limit without fear of arrest. Since drivers of noncommercial vehicles also use radar detectors and since speeding decreases safety for any vehicle, use of radar detectors should also be banned in noncommercial vehicles to increase safety.
question: Why does the fact that traffic accidents involving a truck or bus generally pose a greater threat of injury or death than do other accidents not strongly support the argument?
answer0: This supports banking radar detectors in noncommercial vehicles because it suggests it effectively reduces speeding.
answer1: This information supports the argument that commercial vehicles should not be allowed to use radar detectors, but does not suggest support towards radar being banned in noncommercial vehicles.
answer2: This is not necessary information to the passage towards supporting a ban or not supporting a radar ban.   It would only mean that people using a radar detector would have their detector go off for no reason.
answer3: This would not support a ban on radar detectors as they would not be worthwhile anyway if airplanes and helicopters were utilized.

context: Last year the rate of inflation was 1. 2 percent, but during the current year it has been 4 percent. We can conclude that inflation is on an upward trend and the rate will be still higher next year.
question: Explain why the fact that the inflation figures were computed on the basis of a representative sample of economic data rather than all the available data does not seriously weaken the conclusion.
answer0: Changing the sample size wouldn't necessarily refute the claim that inflation will go up next year.
answer1: Having identified a cause behind the rise in inflation serves to support the author's argument.
answer2: If the cause is truly temporary, the inflation rate may not be as high next year.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A group of 5, 000 undergraduate students was randomly selected from three universities in a large state and asked the question, "Do you plan to attain your master' s degree eventually? " More than 82 percent answered "Yes. " This shows that the overwhelming majority of students want to attain their master' s degree, and that if the national number of students earning a master' s degree is low, it cannot be due to a lack of desire on the part of the students.
question: Why is the reasoning of the argument not considered questionable even though it contradicts itself by admitting that there might be a low number of students earning master's degrees, while claiming that most students want to acquire such a degree?
answer0: 82 percent being an overwhelming majority is a reasonable statement that requires no justification.
answer1: The fact that there is low number of students earning master's degrees even though most students want to acquire such a degree is not a contradiction in the author's argument, only a contradiction in the situation the author is describing.
answer2: The passage only gives the responses from students in one state and uses that to make a argument for national sentiment.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates the introduction of new therapeutic agents into the marketplace. Consequently, it plays a critical role in improving health care in the United States. While it is those in the academic and government research communities who engage in the long process of initial discovery and clinical testing of new therapeutic agents, it is the FDA' s role and responsibility to facilitate the transfer of new discoveries from the laboratory to the marketplace. Only after the transfer can important new therapies help patients.
question: What is the evidence in the passage that allows for the inference that before new therapeutic agents reach the marketplace they do not help patients?
answer0: The author states that researchers are the ones engaged in clinical testing, it does not claim that the FDA should be involved in ensuring quality.
answer1: The passage does not say that testing periods are excessively long, or any longer than they need to be.
answer2: The passage states that new discoveries which are transferred to the marketplace may help patients, not that they definitely will.
answer3: The passage states that new therapies help patients only after transfer to the marketplace.

main_question.question: Which one of the following statements can be inferred from the passage?
main_question.option: The research community is responsible for the excessively long testing period for new drugs, not the FDA.

context: Aristophanes' play The Clouds, which was written when the philosopher Socrates was in his mid-forties, portrays Socrates as an atheistic philosopher primarily concerned with issues in natural science. The only other surviving portrayals of Socrates were written after Socrates' death at age 70. They portrayed Socrates as having a religious dimension and a strong focus on ethical issues.
question: How does the fact that Socrates' philosophical views and interests changed sometime after his mid-forties help to resolve the apparent discrepancy between Aristophanes' portrayal of Socrates and the other surviving portrayals?
answer0: If the later philosophers were interested in the natural sciences, then their portrayals of Socrates would have shown this slant rather than a religious one.
answer1: Whether the atheistic view of Socrates or the philosophical view is more flattering is a subjective issue which depends on the reader’s world view.
answer2: Those who were familiar with Socrates nearer the end of his life would have seen him after he experienced a philosophical shift.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Roger Bacon, the thirteenth-century scientist, is said to have made important discoveries in optics. He was an early advocate of hands-on experimentation, and as a teacher warned his students against relying uncritically on the opinions of authorities. Nevertheless, this did not stop Bacon himself from appealing to authority when it was expedient for his own argumentation. Thus, Bacon' s work on optics should be generally disregarded, in view of the contradiction between his statements and his own behavior.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered flawed for criticizing Bacon's character in order to question his scientific findings?
answer0: The argument does not criticize any of Bacon's opinions so much as it criticizes him for being a hypocrite.
answer1: The character of a scientist is immaterial to whether or not their work is valid.
answer2: Whether or not 13th century science generally holds up has no bearing on whether or not the work of one scientist is valid.
answer3: In most cases it is acceptable to take the remarks of a person as evidence of their opinions, since there is no other way of knowing their opinions.

context: Programmer: We computer programmers at Mytheco are demanding raises to make our average salary comparable with that of the technical writers here who receive, on average, 20 percent more in salary and benefits than we do. This pay difference is unfair and intolerable. Mytheco executive: But many of the technical writers have worked for Mytheco longer than have many of the programmers. Since salary and benefits at Mytheco are directly tied to seniority, the 20 percent pay difference you mention is perfectly acceptable.
question: Why is it not necessary to clarify how the Mytheco executive's salary compares with that of the programmers in order to evaluate the adequacy of the executive's response?
answer0: A change is job within the company is not relevant to the salary that one is given.
answer1: The focus is on whether or not the salary of programmers are fair in comparisson to that of writers not overall benefit packages.
answer2: Since the executive is stating that the salary is based off of senority and not job title than comparing two workers that have similar senority should be getting similar wages.

context: The makers of Activite, a natural dietary supplement, claim that it promotes energy and mental alertness. To back up their claim, they offer a month' s supply of Activite free to new customers. Clearly, Activite must be effective, since otherwise it would not be in the company' s interest to make such an offer.
question: Explain why the fact that a dietary supplement contains only natural ingredients does not weaken the argument.
answer0: Even if there are less expensive dietary supplements on the market that are just as effective as Activite that does not mean that Activite is not effective.
answer1: The handling fee is a source of revenue for the company whether the customer finds the product effective or not.
answer2: The natural ingredients or potential harmful side effects are not part of the argument about the free month' s supply showing that the product is effective.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Principle: When none of the fully qualified candidates for a new position at Arvue Corporation currently works for that company, it should hire the candidate who would be most productive in that position. Application: Arvue should not hire Krall for the new position, because Delacruz is a candidate and is fully qualified.
question: Why does the fact that Krall works for Arvue but Delacruz is the candidate who would be most productive in the new position not justify the application of the principle?
answer0: If Krall works for Arvue, Krall would have gotten the job as the principle applies only when none of the candidates for the new position currently work for the company.
answer1: If the company should hire the candidate who would be most productive in the new position in the absence of a candidate who currently works for the company, this indicates Delacruz is the candidate who would be most productive in the new position as well as that there are no candidates currently employed by the organization.
answer2: If several candidates currently work for Arvue and Krall and Delacruz do not, neither would be considered for the new position.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Famous personalities found guilty of many types of crimes in well-publicized trials are increasingly sentenced to the performance of community service, though unknown defendants convicted of similar crimes almost always serve prison sentences. However, the principle of equality before the law rules out using fame and publicity as relevant considerations in the sentencing of convicted criminals.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the statements above strongly support the conclusion that the sentencing of celebrities to community service instead of prison constitutes a violation of the principle of equality before the law in many cases?
answer0: There is no consideration given to the type of crimes by certain people. All people are considered the same in the law being applied.
answer1: By considering a persons station in life it violates the principle of equality. The law rules out using fame and publicity as relevant considerations in the sentencing of convicted criminals.
answer2: The principle of equality before the law is that fame or any other circumstance cannot override the law.
answer3: None of the above choices

However, the principle of equality before the law rules out using fame and publicity as relevant considerations in the sentencing of convicted criminals.
main_question.question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following conclusions?
main_question.option: The sentencing of celebrities to community service instead of prison constitutes a violation of the principle of equality before the law in many cases.

context: Jackson City has outgrown its current fire station. The existing station cannot be expanded to fit the city' s needs because of building code restrictions. Real estate in the area of the existing station is far more expensive than building space on the west side of the city. Since the price of a building is a considerable portion of the total cost, it would be more economical to move the fire station to the west side of the city.
question: Explain why the fact that city residents have expressed approval of the plan to move the city's fire station to the west side of the city does not seriously undermine the argument's conclusion.
answer0: If the insurance costs reach a certain threshold, any savings earned from changing locations would be lost.
answer1: The nuisance of noise pollution for the residents wouldn’t affect the cost of the project.
answer2: If there is ample water supply on the west side, that would help the case because they wouldn’t incur the costs of running new water lines.
answer3: If the residents approve of the plan, it would help strengthen the argument because the developers wouldn’t have costly delays.

context: Pieces of music consist of sounds and silences presented to the listener in a temporal order. A painting, in contrast, is not presented one part at a time to the viewer; there is thus no particular path that the viewer' s eye must follow in order to "read" the painting. Ttherefore, an essential distinction between the experiences of hearing music and of viewing paintings is that hearing music has a temporal dimension but viewing a painting has none.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be invalid due to its reliance on the metaphor of "reading" to characterize how a painting is viewed, which presupposes the correctness of the conclusion to be drawn on the basis of that characterization?
answer0: Viewing a painting is taking in sensory perceptions through the eyes which is bound by time like all sensory phenomena, while experiencing without consciousness of the passage of time is a delusion or hallucination of the mind.
answer1: People are free to watch a painting in their own individual ways but they will still focus on one part at a time, so the temporal dimension still exists.
answer2: This argument is assuming the exact opposite of what the passage actually posits, which is that "reading" is akin to listening but not to viewing a painting.
answer3: The point of the argument is not seeking commonalities between music and painting but differences between them.

context: Pieces of music consist of sounds and silences presented to the listener in a temporal order. A painting, in contrast, is not presented one part at a time to the viewer; there is thus no particular path that the viewer' s eye must follow in order to "read" the painting. Ttherefore, an essential distinction between the experiences of hearing music and of viewing paintings is that hearing music has a temporal dimension but viewing a painting has none.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be invalid due to its failure to emphasize the aspects of music and painting that are shared by both as forms of artistic expression?
answer0: People are free to watch a painting in their own individual ways but they will still focus on one part at a time, so the temporal dimension still exists.
answer1: This argument is assuming the exact opposite of what the passage actually posits, which is that "reading" is akin to listening but not to viewing a painting.
answer2: The point of the argument is not seeking commonalities between music and painting but differences between them.
answer3: Viewing a painting is taking in sensory perceptions through the eyes which is bound by time like all sensory phenomena, while experiencing without consciousness of the passage of time is a delusion or hallucination of the mind.

main_question.context: Pieces of music consist of sounds and silences presented to the listener in a temporal order. A painting, in contrast, is not presented one part at a time to the viewer; there is thus no particular path that the viewer' s eye must follow in order to "read" the painting. Ttherefore, an essential distinction between the experiences of hearing music and of viewing paintings is that hearing music has a temporal dimension but viewing a painting has none.
main_question.question: The reasoning in the argument is flawed because
main_question.option: the argument fails to bring out the aspects of music and painting that are common to both as forms of artistic expression

context: Electrical engineers have repeatedly demonstrated that the best solid-state amplifiers are indistinguishable from the best vacuum-tube amplifiers with respect to the characteristics commonly measured in evaluating the quality of an amplifier' s musical reproduction. Ttherefore, those music lovers who insist that recorded music sounds better when played with the best vacuum-tube amplifier than when played with the best solid-state amplifier must be imagining the difference in quality that they claim to hear.
question: Explain why the fact that many people cannot tell from listening to it whether a recording is being played with a very good solid-state amplifier or a very good vacuum-tube amplifier does not seriously weaken the argument.
answer0: The range of variation doesn't matter, because what is being compared is the best vacuum-tube amplifiers and the best solid-state amplifiers.
answer1: Whether or not many people can tell whether a recording is being played with a solid-state amplifier or a vacuum-tube amplifier is not relevant to the argument.
answer2: It doesn't matter if some vacuum-tube amplifiers are superior to some solid-state amplifiers, because what is being argued is that the best vacuum-tube amplifiers and the best solid-state amplifiers are equal in sound quality.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Electrical engineers have repeatedly demonstrated that the best solid-state amplifiers are indistinguishable from the best vacuum-tube amplifiers with respect to the characteristics commonly measured in evaluating the quality of an amplifier' s musical reproduction. context: When volcanic lava solidifies, it becomes uniformly magnetized in the direction in which the Earth' s magnetic field points. There are significant differences in the direction of magnetization among solidified lava flows from different volcanoes that erupted at different times over the past several million years. Ttherefore, it must be that the direction of the Earth' s magnetic field has changed over time. Since lava flows differing by thousands of years in age often have very similar directions of magnetization, the change in the direction of the Earth' s magnetic field must take place very gradually over hundreds of thousands of years.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument that the direction of the Earth's magnetic field has changed over time requires the assumption that not all solidified lava has changed the direction of its magnetization unpredictably?
answer0: Carbon dating can be used to identify rocks of non-lava origin to see if magnetic direction changed over time.
answer1: If lava flows maintain their direction of magnetization over time and are not affected by other factors after the fact, then the argument for a periodic magnetic change could be supported
answer2: Lava consistency would have to be able to impact magnetic direction, but evidence indicates that regardless of lava type, magnetic direction is consistent across time periods.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: When volcanic lava solidifies, it becomes uniformly magnetized in the direction in which the Earth' s magnetic field points. main_question.option: not all solidified lava has changed the direction of its magnetization unpredictably

context: Like a genetic profile, a functional magnetic-resonance image (fMRI) of the brain can contain information that a patient wishes to keep private. An fMRI of a brain also contains enough information about a patient' s skull to create a recognizable image of that patient' s face. A genetic profile can be linked to a patient only by referring to labels or records.
question: Why does the evidence not strongly support the claim that patients are more concerned about threats to privacy posed by fMRIs than they are about those posed by genetic profiles?
answer0: There is no mention in the passage of the patients being concerned about privacy or even being aware of the privacy concerns.
answer1: Like all medical records, a patient could be reasonably sure that his or her details wouldn’t be shared without permission.
answer2: There is no mention of labeling in association with the fFMRI, only with the genetic profile.
answer3: Since the fMRI can even be used to accurately reconstruct a patient’s face, it can more easily compromise them than a collection of genetic data.

main_question.context: Like a genetic profile, a functional magnetic-resonance image (fMRI) of the brain can contain information that a patient wishes to keep private. An fMRI of a brain also contains enough information about a patient' s skull to create a recognizable image of that patient' s face. A genetic profile can be linked to a patient only by referring to labels or records.
main_question.question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following?
main_question.option: Patients are more concerned about threats to privacy posed by fMRIs than they are about those posed by genetic profiles.

context: Quillium is the most popular blood pressure regulating prescription drug on the market. Giant Pharma, Inc. , the largest prescription drug manufacturer in the country, owns the patent on Quillium. Giant Pharma stock is hitting unprecedented high valuations. As a result, Quillium is by far the most effective drug available in treating irregular blood pressure.
question: Explain why the fact that Giant Pharma gouges its customers on Quillium's price does not weaken the argument.
answer0: Quillium's uses in other areas of treatment are not discussed nor relevant to its efficacy as a blood pressure regulating medication.
answer1: While Quillium may be the most popular and lucrative, it does not necessarily mean it is the most effective. Other lesser known prescription drugs could be more effective just less well-known and so less popular and lucrative.
answer2: Other patent acquisitions are not mentioned nor would they be considered when determining the efficacy of Quillium. Its popularity is another factor considered as well, not just the high stock valuations.
answer3: If Giant Pharma gouged its customers on Quillium's price, it is unlikely it would be the most popular blood pressure regulating prescription drug on the market.

context: Although Damon had ample time earlier in the month to complete the paper he is scheduled to present at a professional conference tomorrow morning, he repeatedly put off doing it. Damon could still get the paper ready in time, but only if he works on it all evening without interruption. However, his seven-year-old daughter' s tap-dance recital takes place this evening, and Damon had promised both to attend and to take his daughter and her friends out for ice cream afterward. Thus, because of his procrastination, Damon will be forced to choose between his professional and his family responsibilities.
question: Why does the argument not proceed by demonstrating that two situations are similar in order to justify the claim that someone with certain responsibilities in the first situation has similar responsibilities in the second situation?
answer0: It is not clear from the passage what harm will result from the person's actions.
answer1: Completing the paper is not a similar situation to attending the recital.
answer2: The passage shows that time must either be spent getting the paper ready or attending the recital and spending time on one of those is incompatible with spending time on the other.
answer3: The passage does not seek to invoke sympathy but is critical of the mistakes made by the person.

context: Between 1980 and 2000 the sea otter population of the Aleutian Islands declined precipitously. There were no signs of disease or malnutrition, so there was probably an increase in the number of otters being eaten by predators. Orcas will eat otters when seals, their normal prey, are unavailable, and the Aleutian Islands seal population declined dramatically in the 1980s. Ttherefore, orcas were most likely the immediate cause of the otter population decline.
question: Why does the fact that the population of orcas in the Aleutian Islands has declined since the 1980s not strengthen the argument?
answer0: If seals don't eat or compete with sea otters, their population numbers wouldn't be related to the sea otter populations based on those two factors.
answer1: Whether or not the prey of sea otters has grown in population would have no relevance to whether or not orcas are the main cause of declining sea otter populations.
answer2: If the population of orcas declined, it wouldn't be a good argument as to why orcas were the main cause of such an increase in sea otters being eaten.
answer3: If a disproportionate amount of sea otters are able to survive in an area inaccessible to orcas, this would add further evidence that orcas are the factor towards dwindling sea otter populations.

main_question.context: Between 1980 and 2000 the sea otter population of the Aleutian Islands declined precipitously. Orcas will eat otters when seals, their normal prey, are unavailable, and the Aleutian Islands seal population declined dramatically in the 1980s. Ttherefore, orcas were most likely the immediate cause of the otter population decline.
main_question.question: Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_question.option: The population of orcas in the Aleutian Islands has declined since the 1980s.

Ttherefore, orcas were most likely the immediate cause of the otter population decline.
question: Why does the fact that seals do not eat sea otters, nor do they compete with sea otters for food not strengthen the argument?
answer0: Whether or not the prey of sea otters has grown in population would have no relevance to whether or not orcas are the main cause of declining sea otter populations.
answer1: If a disproportionate amount of sea otters are able to survive in an area inaccessible to orcas, this would add further evidence that orcas are the factor towards dwindling sea otter populations.
answer2: If seals don't eat or compete with sea otters, their population numbers wouldn't be related to the sea otter populations based on those two factors.
answer3: If the population of orcas declined, it wouldn't be a good argument as to why orcas were the main cause of such an increase in sea otters being eaten.

context: In a certain wildlife park, park rangers are able to track the movements of many rhinoceroses because those animals wear radio collars. When, as often happens, a collar slips off, it is put back on. Putting a collar on a rhinoceros involves immobilizing the animal by shooting it with a tranquilizer dart. Female rhinoceroses that have been frequently recollared have significantly lower fertility rates than uncollared females. Probably, ttherefore, some substance in the tranquilizer inhibits fertility.
question: Why is it not necessary to determine whether male rhinoceroses in the wildlife park lose their collars any more often than the park's female rhinoceroses do in order to evaluate the argument?
answer0: Male rhinos do not give birth, so this information would not be relevant as there is no fertility rate to be measured.
answer1: How many female rhinos are collared does not help to determine the cause of the lower fertility rates.
answer2: The effectiveness of other tracking methods has no bearing on determining whether recollaring affects fertility rates.
answer3: This information would help to determine whether the tranquilizer itself, or some other part of the recollaring process has a detrimental effect on fertility rates.

context: The mathematics of the scientific theory known as "complexity" describes those phenomena that are not quite stable and not quite chaotic. For example, the mathematics of complexity can be used to describe sand dunes: although sand dunes generally retain their shape, the addition of a tiny amount of sand can cause a sandslide. Certain scientists have concluded that there is good evidence that complexity is correct. After entering complexity-based mathematical models of real-world phenomena in computers, they found that the computerized mathematical models evolve much like the real-world phenomena actually evolve.
question: Why does the fact that computers verify that there are mathematical errors in the calculations of scientists not justify the scientists' conclusion based on the principle that if computers verify that there are mathematical errors in the calculations of scientists, then the theories of those scientists are probably incorrect?
answer0: Being neither purely stable or unpredictable in a computer program that is designed with intention does not prove that computers are chaotic.
answer1: Duplicating results give merit to the results.
answer2: Being able to recreate a phenomenon by computer does not mean it does not exist naturally.
answer3: A mathematical error does not prove a theory incorrect.

context: Jamal: It' s incorrect to maintain that current data suggest a weakness in the economy. Stocks are paying higher dividends than ever and corporations' profits are very high. Yet you criticize corporations on the basis of wage data, which are the only data showing a decline. Jennifer: You' re right that only wage data show a decline, but those data are important because they show a shift of income from companies' workers to their shareholders. The statistics you cite mean little to the expanding numbers of workers finding it increasingly difficult to make a living.
question: What evidence from Jamal's and Jennifer's statements leads to the conclusion that they agree about the truth of the claim that corporations are currently making considerable profits?
answer0: While Jennifer may believe that the decline in wages is a worrisome economic trend there is no evidence that Jamal agrees with this.
answer1: There is no information in the passage regarding biases of compilers.
answer2: Jamal states that corporations' profits are very high and Jennifer says that income is shifting to companies' shareholders which shows that they both think corporations are making profits.
answer3: While Jennifer may feel that the priorities of many corporations are misplaced there is no evidence that Jamal agrees with this.

context: Dobson: Some historians claim that the people who built a ring of stones thousands of years ago in Britain were knowledgeable about celestial events. The ground for this claim is that two of the stones determine a line pointing directly to the position of the sun at sunrise at the spring equinox. There are many stones in the ring, however, so the chance that one pair will point in a celestially significant direction is large. Ttherefore, the people who built the ring were not knowledgeable about celestial events .
question: Why does Dobson's argument not contain an error of reasoning due to the conclusion logically contradicting some of the evidence presented in support of it?
answer0: His conclusion is based on the vast number of stones and probability, which does not contradict the evidence.
answer1: No statements absolutely establish his conclusion but some are treated as if they do.
answer2: The opinions of the historians that are mentioned are not treated as if subject to verification, but merely claimed to be in possible error.
answer3: None of the above choices

The ground for this claim is that two of the stones determine a line pointing directly to the position of the sun at sunrise at the spring equinox. There are many stones in the ring, however, so the chance that one pair will point in a celestially significant direction is large. Ttherefore, the people who built the ring were not knowledgeable about celestial events .
main_question.question: Which one of the following is an error of reasoning in Dobson's argument?
main_question.option: Dobson's conclusion logically contradicts some of the evidence presented in support of it.

context: Parents who consistently laud their children for every attempt to accomplish something, whether successful or not, actually erode the youngsters' sense of self-esteem. Children require commendation for their achievements, but if uniformly praised for both what they have accomplished and what they have merely attempted, they will eventually discount all words of commendation. In effect, such children never hear any praise at all.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the overall conclusion of the argument is that children will develop low self-esteem if their parents do not praise them when they succeed?
answer0: The author does not make a judgement about whether the praise is deserved or not.
answer1: The main point of the argument has to do with too much praise, not too little.
answer2: The author gives solid reasons for why a parent should give praise only when appropriate.
answer3: The main point of the passage is about praising children too much not about praising children for their achievements.

main_question.option: Children will develop low self-esteem if their parents do not praise them when they succeed.

Children require commendation for their achievements, but if uniformly praised for both what they have accomplished and what they have merely attempted, they will eventually discount all words of commendation. In effect, such children never hear any praise at all.
main_question.question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the overall conclusion of the argument?
main_question.option: Children's self-esteem will suffer if their parents uniformly praise their attempts to accomplish things regardless of their success or failure.

context: Astronomer: Astronomical observations in many areas have become useless because light from nearby cities obscures the stars Many people argue that since streetlights are needed for safety, such interference from lights is inevitable. Here in Sandsville, however, the local observatory' s view remains relatively clear, since the city has restricted unnecessary lighting and installed special street lamps that direct all their light downward. It is ttherefore possible to have both well-lighted streets and relatively dark skies.
question: What is the rationale for the astronomer's argument proceeding by offering a counter example to a general claim?
answer0: Specially made street lights are more than a simple distinction from traditional ones that pollute the night sky with light.
answer1: The astronomer asserts that, despite people's idea that inference from streetlights is inevitable, specially made lights can co-exist with dark skies.
answer2: Human made streetlights are not a natural phenomenon.
answer3: There is no mention of any scientific authority in the passage.

context: Benford's Law states that most phenomena in nature begin with '1's and '2' s. The law has been shown to apply very accurately to the amount of money listed on people's income statements. Investigators have used this fact when investigating financial fraud, and can often determine when people have fabricated numbers, since the perpetrators will choose varying amounts so that the first number in each of those amounts is distributed evenly from '1' to '9'. Proponents of Benford's Law, ttherefore, argue that as the technique of applying Benford's law becomes even more refined, an expert's ability to determine whether a plaintiff has engaged in financial fraud will become as accurate in determining guilt as a fingerprint is today.
question: Why does the fact that the use of fingerprinting is highly sophisticated since it has had over a century to evolve as a technology not cast doubt on the conclusion drawn by proponents of Benford's Law?
answer0: It is irrelevant to the argument if there are other methods of detecting financial fraud so long as Benford's Law is effective in preventing financial fraud.
answer1: If people who commit financial fraud know about Benford's Law, they will use Benford's Law to choose amounts that will not cause suspicion.
answer2: The amount of time it took for fingerprinting to evolve is independent of the amount of time it will take Benford's Law to develop as a means of discovering financial fraud.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: Benford's Law states that most phenomena in nature begin with '1's and '2' s. The law has been shown to apply very accurately to the amount of money listed on people's income statements. Investigators have used this fact when investigating financial fraud, and can often determine when people have fabricated numbers, since the perpetrators will choose varying amounts so that the first number in each of those amounts is distributed evenly from '1' to '9'. Proponents of Benford's Law, ttherefore, argue that as the technique of applying Benford's law becomes even more refined, an expert's ability to determine whether a plaintiff has engaged in financial fraud will become as accurate in determining guilt as a fingerprint is today.
main_question.question: Which of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the conclusion drawn by proponents of Benford's Law?
main_question.option: The use of fingerprinting is highly sophisticated since it has had over a century to evolve as a technology.

context: In social science research, "highest education level attained" would refer to the most advanced grade or degree achieved by an individual-for some individuals, it may be a grade in grade school, and for other individuals, it may be a Bachelor' s Degree, a Master' s Degree, or Ph. D. (which is considered the highest education level). A recent study has shown a strong correlation between highest education level attained and proficiency in chess. Another result, studied at many points throughout the 20th century, shows a marked positive correlation between highest education level attained and income level.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that, if Jane has a Ph. D. , and Chris has not finished his undergraduate degree, then Jane will usually beat Chris in chess based on the statements above?
answer0: Hard work and dedication are also important and a job and income can not be solely based on the person's degree.
answer1: Just because Jane has a higher degree than Chris whether or not each plays chess is important to the conclusion.  A degree along does not allow you to draw the conclusion.
answer2: Not everyone that plays chess has a formal education.  This assumes that all people who play chess have a formal education
answer3: A person that is proficient in chess does not necessarily correlate to the type of job or income level that one acquire's.  Many people of all degrees and income levels play chess.

context: If something would have been justifiably regretted if it had occurred, then it is something that one should not have desired in the first place. It follows that many forgone pleasures should not have been desired in the first place.
question: Why does the conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that many forgone pleasures would have been justifiably regretted?
answer0: The passage argues the opposite.  It is the desire for a certain pleasure that sometimes leads to regret.
answer1: Correct.  If you can foresee the desires that will lead to regret, you would not seek the pleasure from them.
answer2: Pleasures sometimes lead to regret and is unavoidable. Those are the ones that should not have been desirable in the first place
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: If something would have been justifiably regretted if it had occurred, then it is something that one should not have desired in the first place. It follows that many forgone pleasures should not have been desired in the first place.
main_question.question: The conclusion above follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_question.option: Many forgone pleasures would have been justifiably regretted.

context: Industrialist: Environmentalists contend that emissions from our factory pose a health risk to those living downwind. The only testimony presented in support of this contention comes from residents of the communities surrounding the factory. But only a trained scientist can determine whether or not these emissions are dangerous, and none of the residents are scientists. Hence our factory' s emissions present no health risk.
question: Why is the industrialist's argument not considered to be invalid due to its lack of discussion of the benefits of the factory to the surrounding community?
answer0: The term "health risk" is used the same way through the passage.
answer1: Emissions from other sources in the area have nothing to do with whether the factory is a health risk.
answer2: The benefits to the community have nothing to do with the possible health risks coming from it.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The Canadian elk has traditionally been limited in its geographic range by the presence of elderberries, its primary source of food, which only grow up until a certain point in the tundra. A recent rise in temperatures, however, has seen a spread in the growth of elderberries northwards into the tundra. Ttherefore, the overall range of the Canadian elk can be expected to increase.
question: Explain why the fact that the grizzly bear, the Canadian elk's primary predator, has also started moving north into the tundra does not cast doubt on the argument.
answer0: This does not mean the range will increase or decrease as it states it is unlikely and not impossible.
answer1: Why the elk are hunted has no bearing upon whether or not their overall range will increase.
answer2: The passage does not state anything about the grizzly bear in relation to the elderberries. If the grizzly bears are moving north it would in fact support the argument as they prey on the elk.
answer3: This would not lead to an increase in the overall range of the elk as they would simply move to a new area which would not increase their range.

context: Louis: People' s intentions cannot be, on the whole, more bad than good. Were we to believe otherwise, we would inevitably cease to trust each other, and no society can survive without mutual trust among its members.
question: Explain why the argument is not vulnerable to the criticism that it mistakenly assumes that if two claims cannot at the same time both be true, then they cannot at the same time both be false.
answer0: The statement is actually advocating for a more positive outlook, not a negative one.
answer1: The statement makes the assumption that if bad consequences occur from holding a belief, then the belief must have been wrong in the first place.
answer2: There is no reference made in the article to multiple claims being either true or false.
answer3: The motives of those who made the claim of people being more bad than good, are not called into question, only the validity of their claims.

context: There are about 75 brands of microwave popcorn on the market; altogether, they account for a little over half of the money from sales of microwave food products. It takes three minutes to pop corn in the microwave, compared to seven minutes to pop corn conventionally. Yet by weight, microwave popcorn typically costs over five times as much as conventional popcorn. Judging by the popularity of microwave popcorn, many people are willing to pay a high price for just a little additional convenience.
question: What evidence supports the claim that more money is spent on microwave food products that take three minutes or less to cook than on microwave food products that take longer to cook?
answer0: Three minute popcorn costs more and sells more than foods with longer cooking times, so it follows that more money is spent
answer1: Microwave popcorn as a whole is considered, and it is not necessarily true or relevant that one brand is more popular than another
answer2: Microwave popcorn as a whole sells more than any other microwave food, which is true if there are 2 microwave popcorn companies or 200.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: In virtually any industry, technological improvements increase labor productivity, which is the output of goods and services per person-hour worked. In Parland' s industries, labor productivity is significantly higher than it is in Vergia' s industries. Clearly, ttherefore, Parland' s industries must, on the whole, be further advanced technologically than Vergia' s are.
question: What is the basis for the argument being considered vulnerable to the criticism that it takes one possible cause of a condition to be the actual cause of that condition without considering any other possible causes?
answer0: Parland's higher labor productivity is a distinction that does not presuppose the fact that it is due to technology.
answer1: The evidence that technological improvements increase labor productivity is not inconsistent with any other evidence presented.
answer2: There are many possible causes for Parland's labor productivity being higher than Vergia's and no one cause can be assumed to be the clear reason.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: In virtually any industry, technological improvements increase labor productivity, which is the output of goods and services per person-hour worked. In Parland' s industries, labor productivity is significantly higher than it is in Vergia' s industries. Clearly, ttherefore, Parland' s industries must, on the whole, be further advanced technologically than Vergia' s are.
question: Why is it not valid to criticize the argument for making a distinction that presupposes the truth of the conclusion that is to be established?
answer0: There are many possible causes for Parland's labor productivity being higher than Vergia's and no one cause can be assumed to be the clear reason.
answer1: The evidence that technological improvements increase labor productivity is not inconsistent with any other evidence presented.
answer2: Parland's higher labor productivity is a distinction that does not presuppose the fact that it is due to technology.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Mammals cannot digest cellulose and ttherefore cannot directly obtain glucose from wood. Mushrooms can, however; and some mushrooms use cellulose to make highly branched polymers, the branches of which are a form of glucose called beta-glucans. Beta-glucan extracts from various types of mushrooms slow, reverse, or prevent the growth of cancerous tumors in mammals, and the antitumor activity of beta-glucans increases as the degree of branching increases. These extracts prevent tumor growth not by killing cancer cells directly but by increasing immune-cell activity.
question: Why is it not appropriate to conclude that the statement that if extracts from a type of mushroom slow, reverse, or prevent the growth of cancerous tumors in mammals, then the mushroom is capable of using cellulose to make beta-glucans is strongly supported by the information above?
answer0: The passage is about cancer fighting properties of certain mushroom extracts, not whether mammals can obtain benefits from cellulose consumption.
answer1: The passage asserts that the beta-glucans are what triggers a positive immune response so it can be inferred that more beta-glucans will cause greater immune-cell activity.
answer2: The efficacy of a mushroom in fighting cancerous growth has no bearing on it ability to utilize cellulose.
answer3: The passage only pertains to mushrooms, not other species or organisms.

context: Forty miles to the west of Tucson, a developer attempted to develop an "oasis" glade in the Sonoran Desert. He created a glade that, the developer claims, is as lush and plant-filled as the ambient 35 degree C temperatures allow. In particular, the developer planted several native fruit-bearing plants, such as prickly-pear cactus. Once the glade was established, a number of desert birds and mammals would regularly inhabit the glade, often eating most of the fruit that falls from the plants.
question: What considerations are given that serve as part of an argument that the presence of the desert animals in the glade does not serve as evidence against the claim of the developer?
answer0: Just because the desert animals are attracted to the glade, does not mean that they would have perished without it.
answer1: There is no mention that the fruit was intended to be sold or that there was a need to cover the cost of development.
answer2: The presence of desert animals serves as evidence that the glade is lush and plant filled
answer3: There is no mention of a reduction in temperature or that the plants that were planted were the kind that produce much shade.

context: Psychologists have claimed that many people are more susceptible to psychological problems in the winter than in the summer; the psychologists call this condition seasonal affective disorder. Their claim is based on the results of surveys in which people were asked to recall how they felt at various times in the past. However, it is not clear that people are able to report accurately on their past psychological states. Ttherefore, these survey results do not justify the psychologists' claim that there is any such condition as seasonal affective disorder.
question: What is the reason for not accepting the author's criticism of the psychologists' claim by offering an alternative explanation of the variation in the occurrence of psychological problems across seasons?
answer0: The author's criticism questions the accuracy of respondents' reporting rather than offering any alternative explanation.
answer1: The author attacks the psychologists' assumption that respondents can accurately report their past mental states in order to discredit the existence of seasonal affective disorder.
answer2: The author's criticism relies on an assertion of unreliable respondent recall, not the number of people that may suffer from the disorder.
answer3: The sample population representation is not called into question.

context: A philosophical paradox is a particularly baffling sort of argument. Your intuitions tell you that the conclusion of a philosophical paradox is false, but they also tell you that its conclusion follows logically from true premises. Solving a philosophical paradox requires accepting any one of three things: that its conclusion is true, that at least one of its premises is not true, or that its conclusion does not really follow logically from its premises.
question: Explain why it is not necessary for the statement that philosophical paradoxes with one or two premises are more baffling than those with several premises to also be true.
answer0: The passage does not mention how a paradox with more or less premises would be any less confusing.
answer1: You only need one of the qualifying things to be true according to the passage in this case if you accept that one conclusion is not true than you can solve a paradox.
answer2: Because a paradox is self contradicting, it would be the case that in order to accept a paradox that you would need to accept a contradiction.
answer3: A paradoxes premises can all be true and they can contradict one another, making it a paradox.

context: Nature constantly adjusts the atmospheric carbon level. An increase in the level causes the atmosphere to hold more heat, which causes more water to evaporate from the oceans, which causes increased rain. Rain washes some carbon from the air into the oceans, where it eventually becomes part of the seabed. A decrease in atmospheric carbon causes the atmosphere to hold less heat, which causes decreased evaporation from the oceans, which causes less rain, and thus less carbon is washed into the oceans. Yet some environmentalists worry that burning fossil fuels may raise atmospheric carbon to a dangerous level. It is true that a sustained increase would threaten human life. But the environmentalists should relax -- nature will continually adjust the carbon level.
question: What is the rationale for why a decrease in the level of carbon in the atmosphere does not cause decreased evaporation of ocean water, which can be inferred from the information in the passage?
answer0: Decrease in the level of carbon in the atmosphere leads to a decrease of the level of atmospheric heat, not the other way around.
answer1: Rain washes some carbon from the air into the oceans, where it eventually becomes part of the seabed. When the level of atmospheric heat decreases, less carbon is washed into the oceans.
answer2: When the atmosphere holds more heat, more water evaporates from the oceans, which causes increased rain.
answer3: A decrease in atmospheric carbon causes the atmosphere to hold less heat, which causes decreased evaporation from the oceans.

context: Economist: Some critics of the media have contended that negative news reports on the state of the economy can actually harm the economy because such reports damage people' s confidence in it, and this lack of confidence in turn adversely affects people' s willingness to spend money. But studies show that spending trends correlate very closely with people' s confidence in their own immediate economic situations. Thus these media critics are mistaken.
question: Why is the economist's argument not considered to be invalid due to its failure to take into account the possibility that news reports about the state of the economy are not always accurate?
answer0: The degree to which people are surprised by changes in the economy would not prove the argument false.
answer1: If people that see the economy in a negative light are also more likely to view their individual situation in a pessimistic way, it would invalidate the argument that they aren't related.
answer2: Even if news reports were inaccurate, they could still affect consumer confidence.
answer3: People that don't pay any attention to economic news would be irrelevant in proving whether people's views of the overall economy and their individual situations are related.

context: Yorco and Zortech are two corporations that employ large numbers of full-time workers who are paid by the hour. Publicly available records indicate that Yorco employs roughly the same number of such hourly wage workers as Zortech does but spends a far higher total sum per year on wages for such workers. Ttherefore, hourly wages must be higher, on average, at Yorco than at Zortech, since __.

answer0: This would have no impact on the wage rate already calculated for Yorco.
answer1: This supports the fact that other pay factors such as overtime are not skewing the hourly wage data in favor of a higher rate at Yorco.
answer2: If benefit costs are part of the calculation, then the total hourly rate at Zorco could be higher based on this information
answer3: While this may be true, the comparison between the two companies is not being adjusted for skill or other factors.

context: Due to the profitable but unlawful practice of selling elephant tusks, elephants have been hunted to near extinction by unlicensed poachers. Ttherefore, an efficient way to prevent the hunting of elephants would be to file down the tusks from time to time, thus removing any incentive for hunting elephants.
question: What is the reasoning that justifies the conclusion that the argument requires the assumption that elephants are only valued by poachers for their tusks?
answer0: The passage does not delve into elephants defending themselves against the poachers or the importance of their ability to do so.
answer1: The passage states that filing the tusks would remove any incentive for hunting elephants, which means that the tusks are the only reason elephants are valued by poachers.
answer2: The passage does not discuss the demand and typically the demand increases with scarcity.
answer3: The passage does not state anything about poachers stealing baby elephants and only mentions the value poachers place upon the tusks.

main_question.context: Due to the profitable but unlawful practice of selling elephant tusks, elephants have been hunted to near extinction by unlicensed poachers. Ttherefore, an efficient way to prevent the hunting of elephants would be to file down the tusks from time to time, thus removing any incentive for hunting elephants.
main_question.question: Which of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_question.option: The demand for elephant tusks will decrease as supply dwindles.

context: Conservationist: The risk to airplane passengers from collisions between airplanes using the airport and birds from the wildlife refuge is negligible. In the 10 years since the refuge was established, only 20 planes have been damaged in collisions with birds, and no passenger has been injured as a result of such a collision. The wildlife refuge ttherefore poses no safety risk. Pilot: You neglect to mention that 17 of those 20 collisions occurred within the past 2 years, and that the number of birds in the refuge is rapidly increasing. As the number of collisions between birds and airplanes increases, so does the likelihood that at least one such collision will result in passenger injuries.
question: What evidence does the pilot provide to refute the conservationist's argument that is not based on the accuracy of the figures cited?
answer0: The pilot doesn't dispute the figures, but does point out the missing context of the figures
answer1: The conservationist suggests that the bird population is constant, which isn't true and a significant piece of information
answer2: The pilot is referencing a specific situation and isn't making a universal statement about all situations
answer3: The pilot discredits the figures, but doesn't address any moral principle, which in any case they may or may not share

context: Sasha: Handwriting analysis should be banned in court as evidence of a person' s character: handwriting analysts called as witnesses habitually exaggerate the reliability of their analyses. Gregory: You are right that the current use of handwriting analysis as evidence is problematic. But this problem exists only because there is no licensing board to set professional standards and thus deter irresponsible analysts from making exaggerated claims. When such a board is established, however, handwriting analysis by licensed practitioners will be a legitimate courtroom tool for character assessment.

context: Some educators have had remarkable success with an unusual approach to science education. For example, a physics lesson on the properties of waves might begin by plucking guitar strings. After observing the strings vibrate, students would begin to apply names to the phenomena they had witnessed, such as frequency and amplitude. Only after fully understanding these real-life concepts would they begin to apply abstract terms and equations to the phenomena.
question: How does the example illustrate the principle that familiarity with phenomena facilitates the learning of more formal treatments of these phenomena?
answer0: Learning abstract concepts and then observing phenomena related to the concept forms a building block for full understanding.
answer1: Students can learn without observation, but it is through observation that they better understand the application of the terms.
answer2: Students learn best when teachers appeal to the interests of their students in the service of demonstrating the application of an abstract concept, otherwise its merely amusement.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Environmentalist: The United Kingdom recently instituted a law requiring that foods containing genetically altered ingredients be labeled accordingly. Food producers, fearing that consumers would understand the labels as warnings and thus avoid their products, rushed to rid those products of genetically altered ingredients. Other countries contemplating such labeling should ttherefore refrain, because many crops are genetically altered to be pest resistant; loss of demand for these genetically altered crops would necessitate production alternatives, all of which are dangerous and pesticide intensive.
question: What is the basis for the environmentalist's argument not depending on the assumption that countries that institute new food labeling regulations often experience a change in consumer eating habits?
answer0: The argument made not claims about consumers eating habits.
answer1: The argument claims that manufactures were concerned about consumers misunderstanding labels, but does not say if it supports it.
answer2: The argument makes no claims on if the products were actually consumed less due to the warnings.
answer3: The argument uses the actions of United Kingdom food producers to warn against law changes in other countries.

context: At the end of the year, Wilson' s Department Store awards free merchandise to its top salespeople. When presented with the fact that the number of salespeople receiving these awards has declined markedly over the past fifteen years, the newly appointed president of the company responded, "In that case, since our award criterion at present is membership in the top third of our sales force, we can also say that the number of salespeople passed over for these awards has similarly declined. "
question: Why does the company president's conclusion not require the assumption that Wilson's calculates its salespeople's sales figures in the same way as it did fifteen years ago?
answer0: Since the award recipients have been on decline for 15 years it must necessarily follow that for the author's conclusion to be reached the criterion for selection must be the same as well over that time period.
answer1: Hiring policy and the number of employees does not directly relate to how many of those employees could have earned an award.
answer2: The passage references the top third of the sales force as a population and this does not rely on how their sales figures are derived, merely how many qualify for an award.
answer3: Since the number of salespeople passed over for the award has decreased it would not make logical sense that more salespeople are available to earn the award.

context: Jane: According to an article in this newsmagazine, children' s hand-eye coordination suffers when they spend a great amount of time watching television. Ttherefore, we must restrict the amount of time Jacqueline and Mildred are allowed to watch television. Alan: Rubbish! The article says that only children under three are affected in that way. Jacqueline is ten and Mildred is eight. Ttherefore, we need not restrict their television viewing.
question: Explain why Alan's argument against Jane's conclusion does not make the error of relying on the same source that Jane cited in support of her conclusion.
answer0: The article is more concerned with the perception of the risk, rather than how much risk was actually occurring.
answer1: Alan only shows that Jane's conclusion is flawed, which does not necessarily prove his to be correct.
answer2: The source of Alan's argument may be the same without nullifying its veracity.
answer3: People can still worry a lot about taking a particular risk, even if they believe the actual chances of something bad happening are very low.

main_question.question: Alan's argument against Jane's conclusion makes which one of the following errors in reasoning?
main_question.option: It relies on the same source that Jane cited in support of her conclusion.

context: In Malsenia sales of classical records are soaring. The buyers responsible for this boom are quite new to classical music and were drawn to it either by classical scores from television commercials or by theme tunes introducing major sports events on television. Audiences at classical concerts, however, are continually shrinking in Malsenia. It can be concluded from this that the new Malsenian converts to classical music, having initially experienced this music as recorded music, are most comfortable with classical music as recorded music and really have no desire to hear live performances.
question: Why does the argument not assume that the classical records available in Malsenia are, for the most part, not recordings of actual public concerts?
answer0: The argument is concerned only with the existence of life (intelligent or otherwise) beyond the Earth, not on the existence of intelligence per se.
answer1: The argument is founded on the absence of evidence of ANY life, with no definition of that concept being given.
answer2: The passage makes no suggestion about where the classical records were recorded.

context: A recent study of perfect pitch -- the ability to identify the pitch of an isolated musical note -- found that a high percentage of people who have perfect pitch are related to someone else who has it. Among those without perfect pitch, the percentage was much lower. This shows that having perfect pitch is a consequence of genetic factors.
question: How does the fact that people who have relatives with perfect pitch generally receive no more musical training than do others strengthen the argument?
answer0: The passage only talks about people's tendency to have perfect pitch if they are related to someone else that does, nothing about choosing it as a career.
answer1: The passage does not mention anything about the researchers having perfect pitch.
answer2: The passage alludes to the fact that if you are related to someone with perfect pitch you are more likely to have it already, meaning that you would have to train less to accomplish the same as with someone without perfect pitch.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Advertisement: Anyone who thinks moisturizers are not important for beautiful skin should consider what happens to the earth, the skin of the world, in time of drought. Without regular infusions of moisture the ground becomes lined and cracked and its lush liveliness fades away. Thus your skin, too, should be protected from the ravages caused by lack of moisture; give it the protection provided by regular infusions of Dewyfresh, the drought-defying moisturizer.
question: What is the basis for concluding that the Dewyfresh advertisement exhibits an error of reasoning by relying on an analogy between two things that are insufficiently alike in the respects in which they would have to be alike for the conclusion to be supported?
answer0: Both the process of infusion and the product of the process achieve the similar effect of moisturizing the ground or skin.
answer1: The earth's crust being lined and cracked does not occur at the same time a human's skin would be.
answer2: The Earth's crust is insufficiently alike to the skin of a human being in respects to requiring moisture to draw any conclusions.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Salesperson: When a salesperson is successful, it is certain that that person has been in sales for at least three years. context: Because dried peat moss, which is derived from sphagnum moss, contains no chemical additives and is a renewable resource, many gardeners use large amounts of it as a soil conditioner in the belief that the practice is environmentally sound. They are mistaken. The millions of acres of sphagnum moss in the world contribute more oxygen to the atmosphere than do all of the world' s rain forests combined, and the garden soil industry is depleting these areas much faster than they can renew themselves.
question: Why does the fact that a practice is environmentally sound if it helps to protect rain forests that contribute large amounts of oxygen to the atmosphere not help to justify the argument's reasoning?
answer0: If reducing the amount of oxygen entering the atmosphere is environmentally unsound, then consuming a product which increases the oxygen content faster than such a product can regenerate itself will lead to a net reduction in oxygen addition, and thus by definition be environmentally unsound.
answer1: The argument concerns whether or not a practice is environmentally unsound based on its effects rather than on its inherent characteristics.
answer2: The argument considers only the negative effects of an environmental practice, and does not weight them against any purported environmental benefits in order to assess "soundness".
answer3: The effect of moss consumption on rain forest preservation is not something which is considered by the argument.

main_question.option: A practice is environmentally sound if it helps to protect rain forests that contribute large amounts of oxygen to the atmosphere.

context: Essayist: One of the drawbacks of extreme personal and political freedom is that free choices are often made for the worst. To expect people to thrive when they are given the freedom to make unwise decisions is frequently unrealistic. Once people see the destructive consequences of extreme freedom, they may prefer to establish totalitarian political regimes that allow virtually no freedom. Thus, one should not support political systems that allow extreme freedom.
question: How does the principle that one should not support any political system whose destructive consequences could lead people to prefer totalitarian political regimes help to justify the essayist's reasoning?
answer0: Given that leading people to preferring a totalitarian regime is the cited rationale for why a system (like one which allowed extreme freedom) should not be supported, it's clear that the author is working off the principle that totalitarian systems should be avoided.
answer1: The rationale given by the author is not that any system based on unrealistic expectations about people's behavior is wrong, only such systems that result in consequences leading to totalitarianism.
answer2: The author does not merely limit the undesirability of systems to those that inevitably lead to totalitarianism, but rather any system that may possibly develop into such a system.
answer3: The author believes that in the long run, a different system would come into place anyway and they do not comment on how people would thrive under such a system.

context: Detective: People who repeatedly commit crimes like embezzlement or bribery without being caught tend to become more confident. With each success, they believe that getting caught is less likely. However, the more crimes a person commits, the greater the chance that one of those crimes will be solved. It is ttherefore likely that most people who commit embezzlement or bribery will eventually be caught.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the detective's argument requires the assumption that the majority of people who commit embezzlement or bribery do so repeatedly?
answer0: The passage author argues that criminals repeat their activity and grow in confidence each time, and it is this repetition that eventually exposes them to capture, thus being a necessary assumption for the conclusion.
answer1: The passage argues that it is the increased exposure through repetitive crimes that lead to detection and not carelessness.
answer2: The passage suggests that criminals feel more confident as in bolder in committing future crimes and not that their personal self image is confident.
answer3: Whether or not embezzlement and bribery are more likely to be solved is immaterial to how often criminals are caught.

context: Loss of the Gocha mangrove forests has caused coastal erosion, reducing fish populations and requiring the Gocha Fishing Cooperative (GFC) to partially fund dredging and new shore facilities. However, as part of its subsidiary businesses, the GFC has now invested in a program to replant significant parts of the coast with mangrove trees. Given income from a controlled harvest of wood with continuing replanting, the mangrove regeneration effort makes it more likely that the cooperative will increase its net income.
question: Why does the fact that a controlled harvesting of mangrove wood by the GFC would have little effect on coastal erosion not strengthen the argument that mangrove replanting will increase the Gocha cooperative's net income?
answer0: The author does not argue that the government makes it difficult to take advantage of deductibles, but only insinuates that it is easier to do so when filing taxes online.
answer1: The author does not actually argue that saving money is beneficial, likely because they assume that making that argument is unnecessary.
answer2: The salt production facilities will still be there as the mangroves would be replanted in other areas that are not currently occupied.
answer3: Having more mangroves helps to prevent coastal erosion.

context: Editorial: Our political discussions tend to focus largely on the flaws of our nation' s leaders, but we need to remind ourselves that these leaders were chosen democratically. The real question that needs answering is how our nation' s institutions and procedures enable such people to attain positions of power. Thus, to focus our attention on the flaws of our leaders is to indulge in a pointless distraction.
question: Explain why the argument does not require the assumption that as yet, no one in the nation has made the effort to critically examine the details of the nation's institutions and procedures?
answer0: The passage does not address how focusing on leaders' shortcomings affects public sentiment towards them.
answer1: The author does not assert that there has never been any examination of the country's procedures or institutions.
answer2: The argument unfolds in a series of relevant premises.
answer3: Ethical breaches can be performed by groups other than undergraduates and professionals.

context: Traditional hatcheries raise fish in featureless environments and subject them to dull routines, whereas new, experimental hatcheries raise fish in visually stimulating environments with varied routines. When released into the wild, fish from the experimental hatcheries are bolder than those from traditional hatcheries in exploring new environments and trying new types of food. Fish raised in the experimental hatcheries, ttherefore, are more likely to survive after their release.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument requires the assumption that some fish raised in traditional hatcheries die because they are too timid in their foraging for food?
answer0: Data showing that individuals have undertaken the spending reduction suggested by the hypothesis have indeed seen the results predicted by it clearly strengthens the hypothesis.
answer1: The data concerns adults within an age range which is atypical of first year university students, and so has no bearing on the argument.
answer2: If fish are timid in traditional hatcheries but more bold in others, this lends to them being more bold in the wild if not raised in traditional hatcheries.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: "This company will not be training any more pilots in the foreseeable future, since we have 400 trained pilots on our waiting list who are seeking employment. The other five major companies each have roughly the same number of trained pilots on their waiting lists, and since the projected requirement of each company is for not many more than 100 additional pilots, there will be no shortage of personnel despite the current upswing in the aviation industry. "
question: How does the fact that most of the trained pilots who are on a waiting list for a job are on the waiting lists of all the major companies cast doubt on the accuracy of the conclusion above?
answer0: If there is a common cause it would help justify the data, not go against it.
answer1: We are not given this information in the passage, and it would really have no bearing upon this company if other companies are still training pilots.
answer2: If this is true then it would make sense for companies to continue training pilots as the 400 trained pilots could easily be swallowed up by competing companies.
answer3: The bias of the insurance statistics and/or studies is not called into question
