context: Editor: Many candidates say that if elected they will reduce governmental intrusion into voters' lives. But voters actually elect politicians who instead promise that the government will provide assistance to solve their most pressing problems. Governmental assistance, however, costs money, and money can come only from taxes, which can be considered a form of governmental intrusion. Thus, governmental intrusion into the lives of voters will rarely be substantially reduced over time in a democracy.
question: Explain why the fact that politicians who promise to do what they actually believe ought to be done are rarely elected does not strengthen the editor's argument.
answer0: Even if this were true, if a politician promised to fix these financial problems and later failed, they would not be in office long.
answer1: Promises kept maintains the support of the electorate that got them into office in the first place, so they have an incentive to do what they say.
answer2: A politician's true beliefs is not the issue, its their promises that matter regardless if they truly believe in them or not
answer3: Politicians are elected on the basis of their promises, so acting contrary to those promises once in office would lose the voters' trust and create long term credibility problems with regard to doing what the voters want

question: How does the fact that politicians who win their elections usually keep their campaign promises strengthen the editor's argument?
answer0: A politician's true beliefs is not the issue, its their promises that matter regardless if they truly believe in them or not
answer1: Politicians are elected on the basis of their promises, so acting contrary to those promises once in office would lose the voters' trust and create long term credibility problems with regard to doing what the voters want
answer2: Even if this were true, if a politician promised to fix these financial problems and later failed, they would not be in office long.
answer3: Promises kept maintains the support of the electorate that got them into office in the first place, so they have an incentive to do what they say.

context: One variety of partially biodegradable plastic beverage container is manufactured from small bits of plastic bound together by a degradable bonding agent such as cornstarch. Since only the bonding agent degrades, leaving the small bits of plastic, no less plastic refuse per container is produced when such containers are discarded than when comparable nonbiodegradable containers are discarded.
question: Explain why the fact that technological problems with recycling currently prevent the reuse as food or beverage containers of the plastic from either type of plastic beverage container does not strengthen the argument.
answer0: Whether or not they both can be crushed completely flat has no bearing on how much refuse is left by each.
answer1: If the partially biodegradable containers contain more plastic to compensate for the bonding agents, this would help explain why they could have similar amounts of plastic refuse to their nonbiodegradable counterparts.
answer2: Technological problems affecting both types of beverage containers would not help explain why there's no less refuse than with the nonbiodegradable counterpart.
answer3: The price and preference of consumers for one container over the other does not affect the amount of plastic refuse.

context: Many uses have been claimed for hypnosis, from combating drug addiction to overcoming common phobias. A recent experimental study helps illuminate the supposed connection between hypnosis and increased power of recall. A number of subjects listened to a long, unfamiliar piece of instrumental music. Under subsequent hypnosis, half the subjects were asked to recall salient passages from the musical piece and half were asked to describe scenes from "the film they had just viewed, " despite their not having just seen a film. The study found that the subjects in the second group were equally confident and detailed in their movie recollections as the subjects in the first group were in their music recollections.
question: Why is it not appropriate to conclude that recalling events under hypnosis inevitably results in false memories based on the information given?
answer0: The study illustrates the influence of hypnosis on recall, but not which specific type of media recall it better amplifies.
answer1: As people in the study were just as confident in their memory  of media they were only told they had been exposed to as those who actually had, it shows that the power of suggestion has an effect on recall.
answer2: The study does not assert that hypnosis, will in every case, leads to false recall.
answer3: The study is more illustrative of the power of suggestion in hypnosis than denying its ability to have any affect on the strength of one's memory.

context: According to a review of 61 studies of patients suffering from severely debilitating depression, a large majority of the patients reported that missing a night' s sleep immediately lifted their depression. Yet sleep-deprivation is not used to treat depression even though the conventional treatments, which use drugs and electric shocks, often have serious side effects.
question: Why does the fact that the dramatic shifts in mood connected with sleep and wakefulness have not been traced to particular changes in brain chemistry not explain why sleep-deprivation is not used as a treatment for depression?
answer0: Since the body cannot live without sleep, as soon as they inevitably fall back asleep, the symptoms would return.
answer1: There is no evidence that it is harder to keep depressed patients awake than non depressed people.
answer2: The passage seems to suggest that there actually is a link between wakefulness and brain chemistry, since the depression was eased after skipping a night of sleep.
answer3: The euphoria described wouldn't be a deterrent to using the treatment, but an incentive.

context: Restaurant manager: In response to requests from our patrons for vegetarian main dishes, we recently introduced three: an eggplant and zucchini casserole with tomatoes, brown rice with mushrooms, and potatoes baked with cheese. The first two are frequently ordered, but no one orders the potato dish, although it costs less than the other two. Clearly, then, our patrons prefer not to eat potatoes.
question: What is the basis for the restaurant manager's argument not being considered to commit the error of reasoning of ignoring possible differences between what people say they want and what they actually choose?
answer0: There is no disagreement that abstract sculptures by the same sculptor have been popular as this is stated as a fact in the passage.
answer1: The passage does not make any claims regarding what people say they want, only what they actually choose so any differences would be irrelevant.
answer2: Not wanting to eat potatoes is only one of several explanations for why the potato dish is ordered less frequently than the other two.
answer3: The artistic tastes of the residents of Sumpton compared to those of other cities is not a point of disagreement in the passage.

context: Critic: Works of literature often present protagonists who scorn allegiance to their society and who advocate detachment rather than civic-mindedness. However, modern literature is distinguished from the literature of earlier eras in part because it more frequently treats such protagonists sympathetically. Sympathetic treatment of such characters suggests to readers that one should be unconcerned about contributing to societal good. Thus, modern literature can damage individuals who appropriate this attitude, as well as damage society at large.
question: What is the basis for the critic's argument not relying on the assumption that some individuals must believe that their society is better than most before they can become concerned with benefiting it?
answer0: The article only speaks to how modern literature can damage society.  It doesn't have anything to say about earlier literature.
answer1: The article has nothing to say about individuals from earlier eras.
answer2: The text doesn't speak to comparing different societies.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: A work of architecture, if it is to be both inviting and functional for public use, must be unobtrusive, taking second place to the total environment. Modern architects, plagued by egoism, have violated this precept. They have let their strong personalities take over their work, producing buildings that are not functional for public use.
question: Why does it not logically follow from the statements in the passage that a work of architecture cannot simultaneously express its architect's personality and be functional for public use?
answer0: This is the core point of the text:  egoism in architects has lead to obstrusive buildings.
answer1: Being unobtrusive is a requirement for being inviting and functional, but not necessarily vice versa.
answer2: The article does not state that these two things cannot simultaneously be true, but rather implies they don't complement eachother well.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.context: A work of architecture, if it is to be both inviting and functional for public use, must be unobtrusive, taking second place to the total environment. main_question.question: Which one of the statements below follows logically from the statements in the passage?
main_question.option: Modern architects who let their strong personalities take over their work produce buildings that are not unobtrusive.

context: The director of a secondary school where many students were having severe academic problems impaneled a committee to study the matter. The committee reported that these students were having academic problems because they spent large amounts of time on school sports and too little time studying. The director then prohibited all students who were having academic problems from taking part in sports in which they were active. He stated that this would ensure that such students would do well academically.
question: Why is the director's reasoning not sound for failing to establish that at least some of the time the students will save by not participating in sports will be spent on solving their academic problems?
answer0: The director's argument perhaps incorrectly assumes that students will put effort into furthering their academic success in absence of sports participation.
answer1: The director's conclusion focuses on those who are struggling academically, and does seek to prove a single cause for why those doing well in school are succeeding.
answer2: The article states that there are already gas pipelines located near these three bodies of water, so it is possible for some electrical generation stations to already exist.
answer3: Some of the electrical needs are being met and will continue to be met by the existing natural gas pipelines.

context: Margaret came home after a long day of work to find her front door open and her waste basket knocked over with all of the contents strewn about the kitchen floor. She believes that her dog must have knocked it over in search for some food scraps to eat, but this belief cannot be correct. Her husband took the dog with him to work all day.
question: Why does the stated argument not require the assumption that Margaret has rats in her house?
answer0: There is no evidence that Margaret's husband knocked over the trash.
answer1: Margaret's husband could have brought the dog home on his lunch break but there are other ways for the trash to have been upset.
answer2: Having rats in her house is only one of many possibilities for the mess and how could rats leave the door open?
answer3: There is no evidence to support a raccoon having entered the house.

context: According to ancient records, the first tax that the government of Selea imposed on a basic commodity was a tax of two centima coins on every jar of cooking oil sold in Selea. Tax records show that despite a stable population and strict enforcement of tax laws, revenues from the oil tax declined steeply over the first two years that the tax was in effect.
question: What is the basis for the fact that two years after implementing the tax on cooking oil, the Selean government began to implement taxes on numerous other basic commodities not helping to explain the decline in Selean oil-tax revenues?
answer0: Implementing taxes on other goods after the two year decline would not explain why there was a decline in oil taxes in the two years prior.
answer1: Home production of oil would decrease revenues, however few households choosing the produce their own oil would not likely cause a sharp decline.
answer2: If gifts of oil increased after the tax was implemented, the tax revenue would increase, not decrease.
answer3: Larger jars of oil would explain why revenues declined because the tax was per jar and not based on volume, thus the same volume would be sold in fewer jars.

main_question.option: Two years after implementing the tax on cooking oil, the Selean government began to implement taxes on numerous other basic commodities.

context: The introduction of symbols for numbers is an event lost in prehistory, but the earliest known number symbols, in the form of simple grooves and scratches on bones and stones, date back 20, 000 years or more. Nevertheless, since it was not until 5, 500 years ago that systematic methods for writing numerals were invented, it was only then that any sort of computation became possible.
question: Why does the argument not rely on the assumption that grooves and scratches found on bones and stones were all made by people, and none resulted from natural processes?
answer0: The passage is concerned with the number symbols that we do have, not the ones that could have hypothetically existed.
answer1: The hypothesis doesn't require all grooves and scratches to be made by people, just the ones they are calling number symbols.
answer2: Whether or not they began learning reading and arithmetic prior to being introduced to computer-assisted education would not explain why arithmetic was preferred with this instruction
answer3: The amount of reluctant teachers is not stated and would not explain why one subject is preferred by students over others

context: Psychologist: Satisfaction and happiness with one' s family cannot exist unless families have established strong values of mutual trust, love, and respect. It is obvious then that widespread reliance on movies and electronic media for entertainment has an inherently corrosive effect on one' s family life.
question: What is the basis for the psychiatrist's argument not depending on the assumption that families cannot usefully increase their happiness by using electronic media?
answer0: The article avoids referencing personal happiness explicitly, and instead speaks about its effect on family life more generally.

context: The diet of Heliothis subflexa caterpillars consists entirely of fruit from plants of the genus Physalis. These fruit do not contain linolenic acid, which is necessary to the growth and maturation of many insects other than H. subflexa. Linolenic acid in an insect' s diet is also necessary for the production of a chemical called volicitin. While most caterpillar species have volicitin in their saliva, H. subflexa does not.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer that no caterpillars other than H. subflexa eat fruit from plants of the genus Physalis from the statements above?
answer0: If H. subflexa synthesized the acid in their bodies, it would follow that they have volicitin in their saliva like most other caterpillars, but they don't.
answer1: According to the passage, linolenic acid is a requirement for volicitin production, but it can be true that there are other chemicals that are also required.
answer2: If most caterpillar species have volicitin in their saliva, and volicitin necessitates linolenic acid, then it follows that most caterpillar species must be consuming linolenic acid.

context: Alexia: Our ignorance about the lives of so many novelists is unfortunate. How much deeper and more complete our appreciation of their works would be if we knew more about the personal wellsprings of their thought and art! Malik: I disagree. Because we know virtually nothing of their personal lives, we can resist the temptation to reduce consideration of their works to biography and psychoanalysis, and instead engage each work on its own artistic terms.
question: Why does the dialogue not provide evidence for the claim that Alexia and Malik disagree over whether understanding the personal wellsprings of the work of certain novelists is impossible without knowledge of their lives?
answer0: Alexia states that knowledge of artists' lives is necessary to understand the personal wellsprings of their works, but Malik disagrees about whether that is good or bad, not whether that is true.
answer1: Malik does not dispute that a novelist's work is influenced by their personal life, he merely believes injecting knowledge about their lives onto their work is not desirable.
answer2: Alexia believes that knowing about their lives would lead to a better appreciation of their work, whereas Malik believes their lives would taint any attempt to understand the work on its own merits.
answer3: Malik believes that a psychoanalytic approach is inadequate to understand an artist's work, not their life.

context: Senior Class President: Our school, in suspending a student who verbally challenged his lab partner' s results, has erred by penalizing the student for doing what he surely has a right to do: speak his mind! context: People who switch to a low-calorie diet generally do not lose any weight. This is surprising since it is understood that decreasing the calories in one' s diet, while maintaining the same level of activity, causes one to lose weight.
question: How does the fact that food that are low in calories tend to cost more money not help to resolve the apparent discrepancy?
answer0: If people consume less calories with a low-calorie diet, the caloric difference of engaging in less activity and therefore burning less calories can explain the disparity.
answer1: Whether a person weighs more or less when they start a low-calorie diet shouldn't change whether they lose weight or not.
answer2: If food that's low in calories cost more money, then people would buy and consume even less of it on a low-calorie diet and would logically lose oeven more weight.
answer3: The taste of foods would have no bearing on how many calories they contain and whether or not someone should be losing weight.

question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed for not taking into account the possibility that, even if it gains the power to do so, the city council might never require voting by mail?

answer1: The city council has to power to require voting by mail and is considering it.

answer3: None of the above choices

context: Sociologist: Romantics who claim that people are not born evil but may be made evil by the imperfect institutions that they form cannot be right, for they misunderstand the causal relationship between people and their institutions. After all, institutions are merely collections of people.
question: Explain why the principle that people should not be overly optimistic in their view of individual human beings does not help to justify the sociologist's argument.
answer0: Societies values could vary but that would not determine what those individual values are caused or affected by.
answer1: The sociologist points out that the institutions are formed from the individuals rather than the other way around.
answer2: There is no mention of what people can do as individuals or as groups but rather how people themselves behave as individuals.
answer3: How optimistic someone might be about the human condition does not speak to what that condition is.

context: Advertisement: Last year, Factorial Mutual Fund continued its strong record of investment performance. Investors who included Factorial Fund in their portfolios realized an average capital gain of 15% across all of their investment assets, nearly double the market return. Ttherefore, investors interested in high returns should consider adding Factorial Mutual Fund to their portfolios.
question: Explain why the claim in the advertisement does not rely on the assumption that last year, Factorial Fund outperformed all other funds with similar style and investment objectives?
answer0: How old or large a fund is wouldn't necessarily be relevant to how high their returns are.
answer1: How much a fund's fees cost would not be a factor regarding whether they make large returns on the market.
answer2: It is possible that other funds in the portfolio that are responsible for the increased returns, so Factorial Fund could be falsely being attributed credit if that were the case, meaning they must have reputable information that the returns are due to their fund specifically.
answer3: Even if were true that they performed better than similar funds, all funds with similar style and objectives could have performed very poorly, and Factorial Fund only slightly less poorly.

context: Researchers have noticed that people whose blood shows abnormally low levels of calcium usually have laryngeal polyps, which can permanently damage vocal cords and result in partial or even total loss of voice. In order to reduce the risk of polyps, the researchers recommend a diet high in calcium-rich foods such as dairy and green, leafy vegetables.
question: Why does the fact that fresh vegetables are not always available in all seasons not strongly suggest that following the researchers' recommendation would not be effective?
answer0: There are other foods that are high in calcium besides vegetables and supplements are an alternative as well
answer1: This validates the recommendation or shows that calcium could come from other sources, but does not disprove the benefits from calcium
answer2: While this may be true, this does not invalidate the beneficial effects from preventing their development from a calcium rich diet
answer3: This provides evidence that low calcium levels are caused by the polyps and that normal levels of calcium did not prevent their development in the first place

question: Why does the fact that low levels of calcium can sometimes be remedied with vitamin pills not strongly suggest that following the researchers' recommendation would not be effective?
answer0: There are other foods that are high in calcium besides vegetables and supplements are an alternative as well
answer1: This provides evidence that low calcium levels are caused by the polyps and that normal levels of calcium did not prevent their development in the first place
answer2: While this may be true, this does not invalidate the beneficial effects from preventing their development from a calcium rich diet
answer3: This validates the recommendation or shows that calcium could come from other sources, but does not disprove the benefits from calcium

context: Editorial: Many observers note with dismay the decline in the number of nongovernmental, voluntary community organizations. They argue that this decline is caused by the corresponding growth of government services once provided by these voluntary community groups. But this may not be true. The increase in government services may coincide with a decrease in volunteerism, but the former does not necessarily cause the latter; the latter may indeed cause the former.
question: Why does the editorial not weaken the conclusion of the causal argument by demonstrating that governments do not have to do what community organizations fail to do?
answer0: The argument is not about what authorities need to do where community organizations are lacking.
answer1: The passage provides a potential cause of the correlation other than the one cited by many observers.
answer2: The editorial offers no specific evidence based refutation of the alleged correlation, but rather an alternative explanation to it.
answer3: The passage suggests an alternative causality rather than denying one exists.

context: FastMart, a convenience store chain, is planning to add pancake syrup to the items it sells. FastMart stores do not have shelf space to stock more than one variety of syrup. Surveys of FastMart customers indicate that one-fourth of them prefer low-calorie syrup, while three-fourths prefer regular syrup. Since FastMart' s highest priority is to maximize sales, the obvious strategy for it is to stock regular syrup.
question: Explain why the fact that people buying pancake syrup at convenience stores, unlike those buying it at supermarkets, generally buy it only a few times does not seriously weaken the argument.
answer0: They only have room for one type so they know that sales for this are not as in demand but are needed for other products that are sold such as pancakes.
answer1: There is no indication that someone who buys from a convenience store only buys a few times.
answer2: There is no way of knowing what would bring a higher price in a store based on the information. Just the demand.
answer3: There is no way of knowing that someone who would buy only low-calorie syrup or regular syrup would buy the alternative.

context: Paper and plastic grocery bags are a continuing problem for the city, both as litter and in landfills. To discourage their use, the city has proposed a tax on each bag, to be paid by the supermarkets that supply them. Several environmental groups, however, oppose the tax, despite having brought the issue to the council' s attention in the first place.
question: What is the reason for the environmental groups' opposition to the proposed tax not being explained by the fact that only supermarkets distributing more than a certain number of grocery bags each month would be subject to the proposed tax?
answer0: The environmental groups want to discourage plastic and paper use among consumers, regardless of how many bags supermarkets distribute.
answer1: That plastic bags are an issue is not disputed among the city and environmental groups.
answer2: How complicated a particular subject is does not relate to the author's main conclusion.
answer3: The passage does not conclude whether independent or guided studies are necessarily more effective than the other.

context: A recent study found that snoring, though not common in either group, is more common among smokers than among nonsmokers. On the basis of this evidence, the author hypothesized that smoking by itself can induce snoring.
question: How does the fact that stress induces both snoring and smoking in certain individuals cast doubt on the author's hypothesis?
answer0: Even if most smokers don't snore, the incidence of snoring is still more common among smokers than non-smokers.
answer1: A third effect, throat problems, being caused by smoking and snoring have no relation on the cause and effect between smoking and snoring.
answer2: Even if out of the set of snorers, most don't smoke, that isn't related to the set of smokers who do snore.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: The introduction of the new drugs into the market is frequently prevented by a shortage of human subjects for the clinical trials needed to show that the drugs are safe and effective. Since the lives and health of people in future generations may depend on treatments that are currently experimental, practicing physicians are morally in the wrong when, in the absence of any treatment proven to be effective, they fail to encourage suitable patients to volunteer for clinical trials.
question: How does the fact that physicians have an overriding moral and legal duty to care for the health and safety of their current patients cast doubt on the conclusion of the argument?
answer0: If the drugs are mainly for those with no treatment options, that would help support the main point of the passage.
answer1: If everyone had a moral obligation to alleviate suffering, then it would make sense for them to sign up for the trials.
answer2: The passage is suggesting that the patients volunteer for the trials, so requiring patients to be a part of the trials before receiving meds wouldn’t hurt the author’s suggestion.
answer3: The physicians cannot suggest trials that would likely cause more harm to their patients in order to help future generations.

context: To be great, an artwork must express a deep emotion, such as sorrow or love. But an artwork cannot express an emotion that the artwork' s creator is incapable of experiencing.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer that the greatest art is produced by those who have experienced the deepest emotions from the statements above?
answer0: Great artists could just as easily be capable of making bad art from time to time.
answer1: the article only speaks about a lack of emotion inhibiting someone's appreciation of art, and has nothing to say about what it takes to make the greatest art
answer2: This is an implication of the text, as it speaks of emotionless creators being incapable of creating great art.
answer3: The text only states deep emotion is a prerequisite for great art, not that it automatically makes it great.

context: Politician: The current crisis in mathematics education must be overcome if we are to remain competitive in the global economy. question: Why is it valid to conclude that the current crisis in mathematics education will not be overcome unless students spend a significant amount of time outside of class studying mathematics based on the statements above?
answer0: The author suggests that in order for a student to fully grasp and learn the subject that they will need to spend time outside of class to understand it.
answer1: The passage is concerned with the decrease in fast-food restaurants, not regular restaurants, so the fast food establishments would still be in jeopardy.

context: When investigators discovered that the director of a local charity had repeatedly overstated the number of people his charity had helped, the director accepted responsibility for the deception. However, the investigators claimed that journalists were as much to blame as the director was for inflating the charity' s reputation, since they had naively accepted what the director told them, and simply reported as fact the numbers he gave them.
question: How does the principle that anyone who presents as factual a story that turns out to be untrue without first attempting to verify that story is no less responsible for the consequences of that story than anyone else is help to justify the investigators' claim?
answer0: The passage states that the journalists are equally responsible, not more responsible, and it makes no mention of whether the lie was for a good or bad cause.
answer1: If the journalists who failed to vet the story is as responsible for the information as anyone else, this would back up the investigators' claim that the journalists are as much to blame as the director.
answer2: Whether or not this is true, it's unrelated to the investigators' claims that journalists are equally at fault.
answer3: The passage is in regards to the blame afforded to some parties, not whether those parties can be labeled as liars.

context: Doctor: Angiotensinogen is a protein in human blood. Typically, the higher a person' s angiotensinogen levels are, the higher that person' s blood pressure is. Disease X usually causes an increase in angiotensinogen levels. Ttherefore, disease X must be a cause of high blood pressure.
question: What is the basis for not considering the doctor's argument to be vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it overlooks the possibility that even if a condition causally contributes to a given effect, other factors may fully counteract that effect in the presence of that condition?
answer0: Whether or not Disease X has other factors that would fully counteract (and thus reduce) high angiotensinogen levels is not discussed, simply that it causes high angiotensinogen levels.
answer1: A third phenomenon could be caused by a first phenomenon that causes a second which causes the third.
answer2: If it is a necessary condition, it would likely be a sufficient condition.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Radioactive waste from nuclear power plants has been temporarily stored on-site, but this is not a satisfactory kind of place for long-range storage. Since no suitable plan of safe permanent storage of such waste from the nation' s existing and planned nuclear plants has been devised, some people propose that we should stop trying to develop such a plan and instead should shut down all present nuclear plants and build no new nuclear plants.
question: Why does the proposal not provide a complete solution to the problem it addresses even if it is assumed that it distinguishes between nuclear plants that have, and plants that do not have, a reputation for operating safely?
answer0: When the risks or benefits come into play are not relevant to the author's argument regarding the undesirability of any waste at all.
answer1: They suggest abandoning plans to store nuclear waste, not abandoning plans to invent safe technologies for producing power.
answer2: The author suggests shutting down all present nuclear plants and not building new ones, but does not offer anything to do regarding the waste that exists.
answer3: All nuclear plants create some waste, so whether or not they operate safely or not would not stop them from adding onto the waste which is the author's problem.

context: A recent study has found that, surprisingly, the risk of serious injuries to workers is higher in industries that are monitored by government safety inspectors than in industries that are not so monitored.
question: What is the basis for the finding not being explained by the fact that government safety inspectors do not have the authority to enforce safety regulations?
answer0: If the government safety inspectors are only monitoring high-risk industries, it is not surprising that the largest number of injuries would occur in the industries they monitor compared to the ones they don't (which are low risk industries).
answer1: This is false. Government safety inspectors do have the authority to enforce safety regulations and when they do, accidents should go down in number, not up, thereby decreasing, not increasing, risk of injury.
answer2: If the government safety inspectors are training employees in addition to monitoring them, one would expect the risk of injury to go down, and not up, due to this training and monitoring.
answer3: If the workers did behave especially cautiously when they believe their performance is being monitored by government safety inspectors, one would expect the risk of injury to go down, not up, due to the extra care and caution taking place.

context: That long-term cigarette smoking can lead to health problems including cancer and lung disease is a scientifically well-established fact. Contrary to what many people seem to believe, however, it is not necessary to deny this fact in order to reject the view that tobacco companies should be held either morally or legally responsible for the poor health of smokers. After all, excessive consumption of candy undeniably leads to such health problems as tooth decay, but no one seriously believes that candy eaters who get cavities should be able to sue candy manufacturers.
question: Why does the main point of the argument not suggest that if candy manufacturers were held responsible for tooth decay among candy eaters then tobacco companies should also be held responsible for health problems suffered by smokers?
answer0: People make their own decisions and know the risks such as eating candy leads to tooth decay.
answer1: No one is denying the fact that smoking causes health problems.
answer2: The candy makers are not held responsible but the tobacco companies are.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Sonya: The government of Copeland is raising the cigarette tax. Copeland' s cigarette prices will still be reasonably low, so cigarette consumption will probably not be affected much. Consequently, government revenue from the tax will increase. Raoul: True, smoking is unlikely to decrease, because Copeland' s cigarette prices will still not be high. They will, however, no longer be the lowest in the region, so we might begin to see substantial illegal sales of smuggled cigarettes in Copeland.
question: Why does Raoul not respond to Sonya's argument by arguing that her conclusion would be better supported if she could cite a precedent for what she predicts will happen?
answer0: He does not argue that her conclusion would be better supported by any means.
answer1: He does not argue about the boldness of any certain intiative.
answer2: He points out the fact that potential illegal sales could affect government revenue from cigarette sales even though consumption is unlikely to decrease.
answer3: The conclusions drawn about consumption and government revenue does not hinge on a distinction between no change and no decrease.

context: The presence of bees is necessary for excellent pollination, which, in turn, usually results in abundant fruits and vegetables. Establishing a beehive or two near one' s garden ensures the presence of bees. Keeping bees is economical, however, only if the gardener has a use for homegrown honey. Thus, gardeners who have no use for homegrown honey will tend not to have beehives, so their gardens will fail to have excellent pollination.
question: Explain why the argument does not commit the flaw of confusing what is necessary for an abundance of fruits and vegetables with what is usually conducive to it.
answer0: Pollination by bees is necessary for an abundance of fruits and vegetables, not just conducive to it.
answer1: Gardeners who have no use for homegrown honey could still have many naturally occurring beehives near their garden.
answer2: Gardeners who have no use for homegrown honey could also establish beehives in order to help the declining bee population.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Writer: I collaborated with another writer on my last book, instead of writing alone as I usually do. Because the book sold so well as a result of this joint effort, I should collaborate with a writer on my next book so that book will sell well too.
question: Explain why the principle that writers who collaborate on books, if they are good writers, usually produce books that sell well does not help to justify the reasoning above.
answer0: The author believes that collaboration will guarantee the book selling well, so a solo book having a lesser likelihood of selling well isn't a strong supporting point.
answer1: The passage states nothing about the quality of the writers.
answer2: The passage does not state that the writer should collaborate with the same writer, merely that their next work must be a collaboration.
answer3: It is true that the author's book sold well because of a collaboration, so the notion that future collaborations will also sell well suggests the author's rationale that they should collaborate again to sell well is sensible.

context: When Copernicus changed the way we think about the solar system, he did so not by discovering new information, but by looking differently at information already available. Edward Jenner' s discovery of a smallpox vaccine occurred when he shifted his focus to disease prevention from the then more common emphasis on cure. History is replete with breakthroughs of this sort.
question: Explain why the examples do not illustrate the ability to look at information from a different point of view being rare?
answer0: It deals more with the ability to look at information from a different point of view being crucial to a breakthrough, not that it is rare in general.
answer1: The article gives a reason for great intellectual accomplishments happening, rather than implying anything happens by chance.
answer2: This is exactly what the text means by thinking differently leading to breakthroughs.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.question: The examples provided above illustrate which one of the following?
main_question.option: The ability to look at information from a different point of view is rare.

context: "Physicalists" expect that ultimately all mental functions will be explainable in neurobiological terms. Achieving this goal requires knowledge of neurons and their basic functions, a knowledge of how neurons interact, and a delineation of the psychological faculties to be explained. At present, there is a substantial amount of fundamental knowledge about the basic functions of neurons, and the scope and character of such psychological capacities as visual perception and memory are well understood. Thus, as the physicalists claim, mental functions are bound to receive explanations in neurobiological terms in the near future.
question: What is the basis for determining that the passage contains an error in its reasoning due to the lack of indication that any knowledge has been achieved about how neurons interact?
answer0: The passage states there is a substantial amount of fundamental knowledge about the basic functions of neurons. A detailed account is not needed.
answer1: Achieving the goal requires three conditions to be met and the third regarding neuron interaction is not stated as having been met.
answer2: The differences in definitions between "neurobiological" and "mental" would not change the overall meaning of the passage.
answer3: The conclusion agrees with the claim of the physicalists.

context: Rabbits were introduced to Numa Island in the nineteenth century. Overgrazing by the enormous population of rabbits now menaces the island' s agriculture. The government proposes to reduce the population by using a virus that has caused devastating epidemics in rabbit populations elsewhere. There is, however, a chance that the virus will infect the bilby, an endangered native marsupial. The government' s plan, ttherefore, may serve the interests of agriculture but will clearly increase the threat to native wildlife.
question: Why does the fact that there are no species of animals on the island that prey on the rabbits not weaken the argument?
answer0: This just confirms that this will kill the rabbits, it does not further the discussion of the ethics of it.
answer1: If the rabbits are already harming the bilbies than it is worth killing the rabbits even if it might endanger the billbies.
answer2: This would be an argument to kill the rabbits, it shows that they will always be invasive.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: One sure way you can tell how quickly a new idea -- for example, the idea of "privatization" -- is taking hold among the population is to monitor how fast the word or words expressing that particular idea are passing into common usage. Professional opinions of whether or not words can indeed be said to have passed into common usage are available from dictionary editors, who are vitally concerned with this question.
question: Why does the method described above for determining how quickly a new idea is taking hold not rely on the assumption that dictionary editors have exact numerical criteria for telling when a word has passed into common usage?
answer0: Nothing concerning the criteria editors use is discussed in the text
answer1: The editors offer opinions on whether the word has taken hold already rather than serving has gatekeepers for new ideas.
answer2: The text does not concern itself with the idea being understood.
answer3: The meaning has to settle enough to be included in a dictionary.

context: Manager: When Sullivan was passed over for promotion, people said that the deciding factor was his being much older than the competition. But this is clearly not the case. Several recent promotions have been given to people older than Sullivan.
question: Why is the manager's argument considered vulnerable to criticism for failing to consider the possibility that the people older than Sullivan who were promoted had no younger competitors?
answer0: The author assumes that age was the only contributing factor and that other factors such as experience were not taken into account.
answer1: The book collector states that the rise of the internet and its search capabilities are responsible, so those things would make the ease of finding such books higher and the increased demand would be sensible.
answer2: Not only is Sullivan's age a factor but the ages of all people up for promotion at the same tiem.
answer3: The ratio of people wanting books in print or out-of-print would not relate to the book collector's statement that the internet has produced more demand for out-of-print books.

context: Economist: During a recession, a company can cut personnel costs either by laying off some employees without reducing the wages of remaining employees or by reducing the wages of all employees without laying off anyone. Both damage morale, but layoffs damage it less, since the aggrieved have, after all, left. Thus, when companies must reduce personnel costs during recessions, they are likely to lay off employees.
question: How does the fact that some companies will be unable to make a profit during recessions no matter how much they reduce personnel costs not strengthen the economist's reasoning?
answer0: The overall efficacy of reducing personnel costs as regards making profits does not make the case that one form of reduction is any more effective than another.
answer1: The argument concerns a choice between alternative strategies for employee cost reduction; it is not concerned with either wage increases or recruitment.
answer2: Recruitment problems which can follow from making layoffs would in fact weaken the argument that layoffs are preferable to general wage reductions.
answer3: If morale is the most important concern when choosing between alternative cost reduction strategies, then the strategy which produces the highest morale amongst the remaining workforce should be the one implemented.

context: In an experiment, researchers played a series of musical intervals -- two-note sequences -- to a large, diverse group of six-month-old babies. They found that the babies paid significantly more attention when the intervals were perfect octaves, fifths, or fourths than otherwise. These intervals are prevalent in the musical systems of most cultures around the world. Thus, humans probably have a biological predisposition to pay more attention to those intervals than to others.
question: How does the fact that several similar experiments using older children and adults found that these subjects, too, had a general tendency to pay more attention to octaves, fifths, and fourths than to other musical intervals not strengthen the argument?
answer0: This strengthens the argument because without this requirement environmental causation cannot be ruled out.
answer1: Such exposure to the environment of world music, which mostly favors two-note intervals, makes the biological predisposition argument invalid.
answer2: It is impossible to rule out the cultural or environmental influence in older children and adults.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Shy adolescents often devote themselves totally to a hobby to help distract them from the loneliness brought on by their shyness. Sometimes they are able to become friends with others who share their hobby. But if they lose interest in that hobby, their loneliness may be exacerbated. So developing an all-consuming hobby is not a successful strategy for overcoming adolescent loneliness.
question: Why does the argument not depend on the assumption that shy adolescents devote themselves to hobbies mainly because they want to make friends?
answer0: The author notes that adolescents devote themselves to hobbies to distract from loneliness not to make friends.
answer1: Shy adolescents use hobbies to avoid making friends and thus their interest level in the hobby is not related to how many friends they make in the hobby.
answer2: Overcoming loneliness necessitates loneliness diminishing over time, as the author notes avoidance does not do this and thus is an example of not being a successful strategy.
answer3: The author's argument only notes that an all consuming hobby is not a successful strategy not that other strategies are better or worse.

context: Criticism that the press ignores positive stories and focuses solely on salacious stories neglects to consider that the press must make a profit to survive. Because of the need to make a profit, the press must focus on stories that will draw an audience. The only alternative to a profit-driven press is a government-supported press. A government-supported press would have pressure to curtail any critique of the government, thereby limiting the power of the press.
question: What evidence is there that the power of the press does not come from its ability to tell a good story?
answer0: The author points out that there are two main focuses of the press which are writing for profit and writing to critique the government.
answer1: The author offers several reasons for why the press reports but does not mention a desire to seek the truth.
answer2: The press sometimes cover salacious stories in order to make a profit but it is not the sole reason nor does it give them power.
answer3: The authoer does not focus on how well the press can tell a story but the focus on why id is being done.

context: A hardware store generally sells roughly equal numbers of Maxlast brand hammers and Styron brand hammers. Last week, all of the Maxlast hammers were put on sale and placed in a display case just inside the store entrance while the Styron hammers retained their usual price and location. Surprisingly, the Styron hammers slightly outsold the Maxlast hammers.
question: What is the reason for the hardware store circulating flyers that publicized the sale prices on Maxlast hammers not explaining the surprising result?
answer0: If the Maxlast hammers were being promoted in flyers, one would expect them to be more popular than the Styron hammers which weren't promoted.
answer1: One would still expect those shoppers that were in the store already to buy the cheaper hammer.
answer2: One would expect that the customers would walk right by the Maxlast hammers as they immediately entered the store and not see the promotional display.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Because it permits a slower and more natural rhythm of life, living in the country is supposed to be more healthy and relaxed than living in the city. But surveys show that people living in the country become ill as often and as seriously as people living in the city, and that they experience an equal amount of stress.
question: What is the reason for why the statements do not provide support for the claim that the amount of stress a person experiences depends on that person's rhythm of life?
answer0: This passage kind of disputes this line of thinking, living in the country should have a slower rhythm yet they experience the same amount of stress as a city dweller.
answer1: This passage is not saying this specifically, just that a natural rhythm might not have as many benefits as people want to believe.
answer2: The passage kind of focuses on both the thoughts that living in the country should be healthier but surveys show that it is not the case.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Commentator: The theory of trade retaliation states that countries closed out of any of another country's markets should close some of their own markets to the other country in order to pressure the other country to reopen its markets. If every country acted according to this theory, no country would trade with any other.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the commentator's argument relies on the assumption that for any two countries, at least one has some market closed to the other?
answer0: The assertion may not be supported by any evidence provided, but that does not mean the evidence is impossible to prove or refute.
answer1: The argument does not assume that protecting domestic producers is the reason for trade retaliation, instead it assumes that the reason for retaliation is to force a trading partner to open its own market.
answer2: If two countries, in all cases, had their markets open to each other the commentator's argument would be baseless because there would be no cause for retaliation in any case.
answer3: The ad does not attack the source of the rival product's claims.

main_question.context: Commentator: The theory of trade retaliation states that countries closed out of any of another country's markets should close some of their own markets to the other country in order to pressure the other country to reopen its markets. If every country acted according to this theory, no country would trade with any other.
main_question.question: The commentator's argument relies on which of the following assumptions?
main_question.option: For any two countries, at least one has some market closed to the other.

context: Commentator: The theory of trade retaliation states that countries closed out of any of another country's markets should close some of their own markets to the other country in order to pressure the other country to reopen its markets. context: Birds and mammals can be infected with West Nile virus only through mosquito bites. Mosquitoes, in turn, become infected with the virus when they bite certain infected birds or mammals. The virus was originally detected in northern Africa and spread to North America in the 1990s. Humans sometimes catch West Nile virus, but the virus never becomes abundant enough in human blood to infect a mosquito.
question: What is the basis for not concluding that the statements above strongly support the claim that some people who become infected with West Nile virus never show symptoms of illness?
answer0: There are other features that can be used to tell artists apart, but when artists have a very similar style, contours and hatching are very useful.
answer1: There is no information on symptoms that are shown with the West Nile virus.
answer2: Since Michelangelo and Clovio were contemporaries, it is more likely that their styles were similar enough that the untrained eye didn't spot the differences, and less likely that they were deliberate forgeries.
answer3: Not all mosquitoes carry the virus so you could have a low mosquito population and still the mosquitoes could carry the virus. The numbers make no difference.

context: Consumer advocate: Even if one can of fruit or vegetables weighs more than another, the heavier can does not necessarily contain more food. answer3: None of the above choices

context: The number of applications for teaching positions in Newtown' s public schools was 5. 7 percent lower in 1993 than in 1985 and 5. 9 percent lower in 1994 than in 1985. question: How does the fact that new housing developments planned for Newtown are slated for occupancy in 1997 and are expected to increase the number of elementary school students in Newtown's public schools by 12 percent not contribute to an explanation of the apparent discrepancy?
answer0: The author assumes that if all employees are allowed to chose the time they come in that there would be now way to know how many employees there will be at a given time to interact with.
answer1: The arrival time of an employee would not affect their ablity to submit their work.
answer2: If despite increasing resignations, the amount of applications were so much higher than the positions available, it would make sense that there would not be a shortage.
answer3: The increase of future students at the school would not explain the discrepancy measured over a decade before that future point.

context: Until recently it was widely believed that only a limited number of species could reproduce through parthenogenesis, reproduction by a female alone. But lately, as interest in the topic has increased, parthenogenesis has been found in a variety of unexpected cases, including sharks and Komodo dragons. So the number of species that can reproduce through parthenogenesis must be increasing.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument considered vulnerable to criticism for taking ignorance of the occurrence of something as conclusive evidence that it did not occur?
answer0: Specific causation is not relevant to the argument's main conclusion.
answer1: Newly discovered information about how many species utilize parthenogenesis is not necessarily an indication that this number is actively increasing.
answer2: The author's argument has nothing to do with the level of interest there is in the topic.
answer3: There are no key differences present that would undermine the argument being made.

context: A physically active lifestyle has been shown to help increase longevity. In the Wistar region of Bellaria, the average age at death is considerably higher than in any other part of the country. Wistar is the only mountainous part of Bellaria. A mountainous terrain makes even such basic activities as walking relatively strenuous; it essentially imposes a physically active lifestyle on people. Clearly, this circumstance explains the long lives of people in Wistar.
question: How does the fact that many people who live in the Wistar region have moved there in middle age or upon retirement weaken the argument?
answer0: The quality of healthcare is irrelevant in this discussion about more exercise
answer1: The passage mentions it is the natural wonders that provide the benefit not the spending
answer2: This would mean that people would not have had a chance to get any of the reported benefits for much time and would not explain the older age of death
answer3: The size of the population does not matter in the phenomenon that is being observed about older death age.

context: Lathyrism, a debilitating neurological disorder caused by the consumption of the legume Lathyrus sativus, is widespread among the domestic animals of some countries. Attempts to use rats to study lathyrism have generally failed. Rats that ingested Lathyrus sativus did not produce the symptoms associated with the disorder.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that laboratory conditions are not conducive to the development of lathyrism based on the information given?
answer0: The author does not question the whether the amount of Lathyrus consumed matters only how the Lathyrus affects the rats.

answer3: The author states that rats that ingested Lathyrus did not show symptoms thus proving that not all animal species are affected by Lathyrus in the same way.

context: A large company has been convicted of engaging in monopolistic practices. The penalty imposed on the company will probably have little if any effect on its behavior. Still, the trial was worthwhile, since it provided useful information about the company' s practices. After all, this information has emboldened the company' s direct competitors, alerted potential rivals, and forced the company to restrain its unfair behavior toward customers and competitors.
question: What is the reason for not considering the claim that the light shed on the company's practices by the trial has emboldened its competitors, alerted potential rivals, and forced the company to restrain its unfair behavior to accurately express the overall conclusion drawn in the argument?
answer0: These outcomes are byproduct effects of the lawsuit, but not the main conclusion of the passage.
answer1: How the company's behavior may or may not change is not the primary conclusion of the argument.
answer2: The passage does primarily argue that while the company's behavior may not change significantly, the undertaking of the trial was nonetheless valuable.
answer3: No argument is made as to what the size of the punishment should have been.

context: A graduate degree in policymaking is necessary to serve in the presidential cabinet. In addition, every member of the cabinet must pass a security clearance. No person with a felony can pass a security clearance. Rick holds a graduate degree in policymaking, but he has a conviction for driving under the influence. Ttherefore, Rick cannot serve in the cabinet.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion not follow logically even if it is assumed that holding a graduate degree is less important than having a felony conviction?
answer0: Both requirements must be met so one is not more required than the other.
answer1: Since a crime must be a felony to exclude someone from eligibility and Rick got a driving under the influence conviction, this supports that the conviction was a felony since it is what is said to have excluded him from eligibility.
answer2: There is no character judgement made but rather an observation of a requirement not being met.
answer3: There is no mention that having a felony will not cause a failure of the security clearance specifically but that the felony excludes eligibility.

question: Why is the reasoning in the politician's argument not considered to be flawed for not demonstrating that the economists mentioned are not experts in the area of consumer prices?
answer0: It does not call into question the economists level of expertise.
answer1: The character of the economists is not called into question, rather the facts that they have stated are.
answer2: There is no emotional appeal made in the argument.
answer3: The evidence used is from the author's personal observations from around his local area and so is not representative of a larger population as would be needed to make such a generaliztion.

main_question.context: Politician: Those economists who claim that consumer price increases have averaged less than 3 percent over the last year are mistaken. context: Style manual: Archaic spellings and styles of punctuation in direct quotations from older works are to be preserved if they occur infrequently and do not interfere with a reader' s comprehension. However, if they occur frequently, the editor may modernize them, inserting a note with an explanation to this effect in the text, or if similar modernizing has been done in more than one quotation, inserting a general statement in the preface. On the other hand, obvious typographical errors in quotations from modern works may be corrected without explanation.
question: Why does it logically follow from the statements that an editor may modernize punctuation directly quoted from an older work if that punctuation occurs frequently and interferes with reader comprehension?
answer0: The passage suggests that such a correction would not occur unless it was a typographical error, in which case no explanation is necessary.
answer1: The passage clearly states that frequent occurrence and/or infrequent occurrence that does interfere with a reader's comprehension allows an editor to modernize punctuation.
answer2: The passage states that only repeated modernization in a text necessitates an explanation in the preface of a work.
answer3: The passage states only clear typographical errors can be modernized without explanation, not merely archaic spellings.

context: An undergraduate degree is necessary for appointment to the executive board. Further, no one with a felony conviction can be appointed to the board. Thus, Murray, an accountant with both a bachelor' s and a master' s degree, cannot be accepted for the position of Executive Administrator, since he has a felony conviction.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion not follow logically even if it is assumed that an undergraduate degree is not necessary for acceptance for the position of Executive Administrator?
answer0: The passage does not state anything about a master's degree and focuses only on an undergraduate degree being necessary.
answer1: The passage explicitly states that an undergraduate degree is necessary for acceptance for the position, which renders this option invalid.
answer2: This option sums up the main point of the passage that only those who are eligible for appointment can be accepted for the position.
answer3: We are not given information regarding what felony charge Murray was convicted upon so this option would be making assumptions.

context: Politicians often advocate increased overall economic productivity while ignoring its drawbacks. For example, attempting to increase the productivity of a corporation means attempting to increase its profitability, which typically leads to a reduction in the number of workers employed by that corporation. Thus, attempting to increase productivity in the economy as a whole may benefit business owners, but will increase the number of unemployed workers.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed for unfairly criticizing politicians in general on the basis of the actions of a few who are unwilling to consider the drawbacks of attempting to increase productivity?
answer0: Just because one individual corporation uses methods that would lower employment rate does not mean the whole economy would use similar strategies.
answer1: This would be a helpful bit of information that could inform your decision but the single corporation cannot be used as an example for the whole economy
answer2: The  topic is about unemployed workers increasing if productivity is increased not about criticizing politicians.
answer3: None of the above choices

main_question.question: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument
main_question.option: unfairly criticizes politicians in general on the basis of the actions of a few who are unwilling to consider the drawbacks of attempting to increase productivity

context: Amateur gardeners who plant based on the phases of the moon tend to get better results than those who do not. This seems surprising since the phases of the moon do not affect how plants grow. An alternative practice often found among amateur gardeners is to plant during the first warm spell of spring, which leads to problems when a frost follows. So, amateur gardeners who use the phases of the moon are less likely to lose plants to a frost.
question: Why does the argument not require assuming that amateur gardeners cannot improve their results unless they understand why their methods work as they do?
answer0: The variability of the plants is not addressed but rather the viability.
answer1: Understanding the methods has no bearing on which methods works best.
answer2: The substantial growth in mail order fiction sales could be more than the decline in bookstore sales, thus the campaign would not be unsuccessful.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: In order to reduce the number of items damaged while in transit to customers, packaging consultants recommended that the TrueSave mail-order company increase the amount of packing material so as to fill any empty spaces in its cartons. Accordingly, TrueSave officials instructed the company's packers to use more packing material than before, and the packers zealously acted on these instructions and used as much as they could. Nevertheless, customer reports of damaged items rose somewhat.
question: How does the fact that TrueSave has lost some of its regular customers as a result of the high number of damaged items they received not help to explain why acting on the consultants' recommendation failed to achieve its goal?
answer0: The employees stuck as much packing material as the could get into the packages, implying they compressed it to get more into the package.
answer1: There were no reports by customers about how easy or hard it was to unpack their items. There were just reports of damage.
answer2: There was no mention on the costs of using more material so we can not conclude that it cost more.
answer3: There was no mention of customers leaving the company. Only that they reported damage.

main_question.context: In order to reduce the number of items damaged while in transit to customers, packaging consultants recommended that the TrueSave mail-order company increase the amount of packing material so as to fill any empty spaces in its cartons. context: Publishers, like all private businesses, have always been concerned about profitability. But, while it used to be at least possible to get a book published that was unlikely to be popular, and hence unlikely to be a moneymaker, profitability is now the sole criterion. Thus, no matter how much literary merit a book possesses, it will not be published in today' s market if it looks like it will not be popular.

context: Recent investigations of earthquakes have turned up a previously unknown type of seismic shock, known as a displacement pulse, which is believed to be present in all earthquakes. Alarmingly, high-rise buildings are especially vulnerable to displacement pulses, according to computer models. Yet examination of high-rises within cities damaged by recent powerful earthquakes indicates little significant damage to these structures.
question: Explain why the fact that computer models have been very successful in predicting the effects of other types of seismic shock does not contribute to a resolution of the apparent paradox?
answer0: Even if there was confirmation that they accompanied all earthquakes instead of just being believed to, that would only contribute to the assumption that these high-rises should have had more damage.
answer1: The passage solely examines high-rises within cities damaged by recent powerful earthquakes, not low and medium intensity earthquakes,
answer2: If scientific predictions from computer models often fail when actually tested, this would mean that the prediction that high-rise buildings are especially vulnerable to displacement pulses is simply incorrect upon actual examination.
answer3: Being successful at predicting other types of seismic shocks does not imply being successful at predicting displacement pulses.

context: Although most people know what their bad habits are and want to rid themselves of them, a majority of these people find it very difficult to do so. context: A major art theft from a museum was remarkable in that the pieces stolen clearly had been carefully selected. The criterion for selection, however, clearly had not been greatest estimated market value. It follows that the theft was specifically carried out to suit the taste of some individual collector for whose private collection the pieces were destined.
question: Why does the argument not tacitly appeal to the principle that any art theft committed at the direction of a single individual results in a pattern of works taken and works left alone that defies rational analysis?
answer0: The passage is not suggesting that the thief was irrational, but that he or she was motivated by something other than pure market value.
answer1: The passage is concerned with the motivation of the theft and not the damage to the collection of art.
answer2: The husband is not seeking a penalty for an action, but rather violating an agreement and the ability to pay restitution to the husband by the wife is not stated.
answer3: The husband agreed to no seek compensation and then broke the agreement, which the ethicist sees as morally wrong.

context: Cognitive scientist: Using the pioneering work of comparative psychologist Gordon Gallup as a model, several studies have investigated animals' capacity for mirror self-recognition (MSR). Most animals exposed to a mirror respond only with social behavior, such as aggression. However, in the case of the great apes, repeated exposure to mirrors leads to self-directed behaviors, such as exploring the inside of the mouth, suggesting that these animals recognize the reflection as an image of self. The implication of these studies is that the great apes have a capacity for self-awareness unique among nonhuman species.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the cognitive scientist makes the assumption that if an animal does not have the capacity for MSR, it does not have the capacity for self-awareness in the argument?
answer0: This is the correct answer because the cognitive scientist draws his conclusion about animal self-awareness exclusively from the MSR experiment.
answer1: This is false because great apes, like all animals, initially show social behavior but eventually show self-directed behavior thus demonstrating their self-awareness.
answer2: This is not true because the argument explicitly states that of all animals only the great apes initially display social behavior but eventually learn to recognize themselves in the mirror and begin to indulge in self-directed behavior.
answer3: The cognitive scientist does not even consider such a possibility.

context: During its caterpillar stage, the leopard magpie moth feeds on a plant called the Natal grass cycad and by so doing laces its body with macrozamin, a toxin that makes the moth highly unpalatable to would-be predators. Since the Natal grass cycad is now endangered and facing extinction, the leopard magpie moth is also in danger of extinction.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument does not require the assumption that none of the potential predators of the leopard magpie moth have developed a tolerance to macrozamin?
answer0: Since potential predators find the leopard magpie moth unpalatable, they are not able to consume them and build a tolerance.
answer1: Potential predators find macrozamin unpalatable whether they can see it or not.
answer2: If  the leopard magpie moth had other means of making itself unpalatable, there'd be no relation between either going extinct.
answer3: None of the above choices

context: Humans are supposedly rational: in other words, they have a capacity for well-considered thinking and behavior. This is supposedly the difference that makes them superior to other animals. Thus, humans are not rational after all, so it is absurd to regard them as superior to other animals.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be invalid for presuming, without evidence, that humans are no worse than other animals?

context: Professor: A guest speaker recently delivered a talk entitled "The Functions of Democratic Governments" to a Political Ideologies class at this university. question: What is the rationale for why the professor's reasoning is flawed for drawing a general conclusion based on too small a sample?
answer0: The passage does not show intolerance of the students' views and merely gives the reader information as to what happened before the author states their viewpoint and conclusion.

answer3: The conclusion is based upon only one incident and therefore one sample which is far too little information.

context: Nutritionist: The food pyramid was amended to provide the public with a healthier nutrition plan to combat the obesity epidemic. The base of the previous food pyramid -- the grains group -- advised people to eat six-to-eleven servings of pasta and bread per day. In contrast, the updated pictorial nutrition guide shows a plate, and it reduces the percentage of dietary intake of grains and replaces the difference with lean proteins and vegetables. The updated guide has been wildly successful, as citizens have lost a significant amount of weight.
question: Why does the fact that citizens have started to exercise more since the publication of the updated food guide not strengthen the nutritionist's conclusion?
answer0: Heart disease related to pasta and bread does not affect whether people would lose weight eating more vegetables and protein.
answer1: There is no evidence that the makeup of how the pyramid is displayed would have any effect on how people follow it.
answer2: Exercising more would cause weight loss and would be a factor rather than the change in diet alone..

In contrast, the updated pictorial nutrition guide shows a plate, and it reduces the percentage of dietary intake of grains and replaces the difference with lean proteins and vegetables. The updated guide has been wildly successful, as citizens have lost a significant amount of weight.
question: How does the fact that eating more lean proteins and vegetables contributes to weight loss strengthen the nutritionist's conclusion?
answer0: Heart disease related to pasta and bread does not affect whether people would lose weight eating more vegetables and protein.
answer1: Exercising more would cause weight loss and would be a factor rather than the change in diet alone..
answer2: If eating more proteins and vegetables leads to weight loss then changing the recommendation to include larger portions of these types of foods supports the idea that it is the reason people lost weight under the new food pyramid.
answer3: There is no evidence that the makeup of how the pyramid is displayed would have any effect on how people follow it.

context: Despite the best efforts of astronomers, no one has yet succeeded in exchanging messages with intelligent life on other planets or in other solar systems. In fact, no one has even managed to prove that any kind of extraterrestrial life exists. Thus, there is clearly no intelligent life anywhere but on Earth.

context: Of 2, 500 people who survived a first heart attack, those who did not smoke had their first heart attack at a median age of 62. However, of those 2, 500, people who smoked two packs of cigarettes a day had their first heart attack at a median age of 51. On the basis of this information, it can be concluded that nonsmokers tend to have a first heart attack eleven years later than do people who smoke two packs of cigarettes a day.
question: Why is the conclusion not considered to be valid even if the information includes the earliest age at which a person who smoked two packs a day had his or her first heart attack?
answer0: Alberto doesn't list any musical experts when he is making his argument.
answer1: The severity of a heart attack is not the issue but the timing of heart attacks on people who smoke vs those who do not smoke.
answer2: He suggests that Mozart himself might not have heard the music as he intended it to be played, because it was common to add some interpretation to the music as it was being played.
answer3: The ages given are an average and does not mean that someone will have that heart attack at that earliest age given. It could happen even earlier.
